Seek more information on the Dark Queen
11313.content:
Sir Garrett appreciated the hospitality but he knew there were many agents of evil in this swamp and no person grew old here with out being a more than a little dangerous. She was certainly hiding her full potential so there was no reason to put himself in her power. Besides, it had been a long ride out here and he needed sleep more than he needed food. He took a couple bits of jerky and a swallow of water and set about the task of going to bed.

His gear and his horse needed attention before he could go to bed so they would be ready to continue the journey in the morning. It didn’t take long before his body allowed him to go into a deep sleep. A little while later the old woman approached the camp cautiously, she called out to the paladin but when he didn’t respond a dark smile formed on her face.

The paladin carried many valuable items she could sell and he would make a good servant as soon as she could pour the potion down his throat. She moved in to the slumbering form of the large man but she had forgotten that he was well guarded. Thunder kicked out hard at the woman caving in the skull of the woman. A look of shock filled her face for only a moment as she collapsed to the ground dead for the wound. Sir Garrett woke with the noise with his unneeded blade ready to deal death to an enemy.

Sir Garrett gently caressed Thunder,” Thank you old friend. You have saved me once again.”

Thunder nodded happily in agreement before moving over to the sack with his food grabbing it with his teeth before setting in front of Sir Garrett.

The paladin laughed, “Alright you have earned a few sugar cubes.”
11313.title: I'm going to bed, I am tired.

113131.content:
The door protested loudly as he pushed it open to examine the inside, there was a temptation to just set fire to the entire thing but he should see what she had been up to. He was suspecting just a minor hedge wizard but he wouldn’t be sure until he got inside.

Sir Garrett kept his blade out uncertain what he would find. A thousand odors assailed his nose many of them like the herbs were almost pleasant but the bits of animal flesh were far less so. It didn’t appear housekeeping was less than stellar with bits of entrails on the floor. Books were strewn about, cautiously he turned the pages to find various formulas and potions. The languages weren’t familiar to him but the scrawlings looked ominous.

He moved carefully past precariously stacked vials of glowing liquors certain he didn’t want them falling upon him. A couple of heavy blows shattered the lock on a chest revealing a treasure trove of stuff within. The sack within spilled an assortment of metallic coins as well as gems collected from a lifetime of ill-gotten gains. Papers contained information on the woman’s dark dealings but the strangest thing within was the chain mail armor.

“How is this supposed to protect anyone?” the metal bikini hung from the tip of his sword. “Why would she have this?”

It was hidden away and in a protective cloth so it was likely some sort of cursed item.

Nothing else of note was found in the place leaving the paladin with a decision to make before continuing the mission. Many of the items here would be dangerous in the wrong hands but how should he deal with the dangers in the tiny cottage?
113131.title: Inspect the home of the old woman

1131311.content:
The paladin didn’t like what he was seeing. A fortune in dark magic if you could find the right buyer, a curse to the uninformed who stumbled upon it, and may the gods forbid some master of evil to find the place. He didn’t have enough room on his horse for all the stuff and he didn’t want to leave anything behind.

Sir Garrett started gathering the brush from the surrounding area. It wasn’t surprising to find so much deadwood. The spellcrafter had drained the place of life leaving only death in her wake. Soon a lifetime of evil will be burned away by her own doing.

Thunder snorted a complaint as the flames started to burn but relaxed as Sir Garrett returned to join the animal.

“Don’t worry old friend,” he patted the large warhorse. “The fire will soon do its work. I will cover it with some dirt and we can be on our way.”

An unearthly shriek drew the holy warrior’s blade from the sheathe in an instant. Strange streaks of green, purple, and pink filled the air. He didn’t know what to make of what was happening but if some evil came out of there he planned to put an end to it. Sir Garrett drew closer trying to listen closely to the roaring fire to hear if something was moving in the area.

Suddenly there was an explosion. Despite the flaring magic of his shield he was sent him flying backward. Fumes poured towards him as he struggled to get to his feet. Thunder raced over ignoring the hazards to assist his master. Garrett clutched onto his companion leading him away from the destruction. The paladin noticed something strange.
1131311.title: Fire and lots of it

1132.content:
Sir Garrett decided he needed to talk to the lizard men because they would know what was going on with the dread swamp with a little luck. It was there home and they were likely to want the threat gone as much as the King did so he was hopeful they would be allies against the dangers. He had met the species on several occasion and they had always been honorable with him. Lizardmen were often recruited by powerful monsters to serve as an army under threat of death or destruction.

The village he was looking for was at the edge of the swamp and one of the largest communities of lizard men he knew of. To his surprise, he saw a small wooden barricade had been erected around the village. Several of the lizard men stepped forward with drawn blades at his approach so he got off his horse and walked towards them slowly because it looked like they had already encountered the danger of the swamp and it had made them very nervous about strangers.”

“I am Sir Garrett of the Kingdom of Dar,” the paladin tried to calm the fears of the lizard men. “I have come to do battle with the evil rising in the swamp. I hope you can supply me with information or help in ending the threat to your people and mine.”

Nodding in acknowledgment of his words they opened the gate for him and motioned him through. The larger one waved for him to follow and Sir Garrett complied with the request, keeping his eyes open to what was going on in the village. Many he saw were missing limbs or bandaged and for a race that healed quickly, that was very worrisome. He entered a large hut with many herbs and fragrances filling the air. It appeared he had entered the home of the shaman.

It appeared the shaman was cooking something over the fire, food or a magical formula he wasn’t sure. The shaman was missing one eye and the scales looked like the color had dulled with time. The creature observed the human entering for a couple of moments before turning to the lizard man who seemed to explain why he was here in their native tongue. He waved the large lizard man off after he was done talking and motion for Sir Garrett to sit. Sir Garrett sat as the shaman reached back to pull out a container of herbs that he offered the paladin. The shaman motioned for him to eat the herbs.

Sir Garrett hesitated because he suspected they had hallucinating qualities to them and he wanted to keep a clear head if he was going to have to fight some sort of monster. He didn’t want to offend the shaman by not taking it, perhaps he could ask for someone to help him translate so he could be clear about what he was saying and why he was denying the request. He would have to decide soon as the shaman was gesturing again.
1132.title: The lizard people know the swamps better than a...

1133.content:
Sir Garrett decided he wanted to complete this mission as soon as possible so he sent Thunder to a nearby monastery of his order. His horse would find the way with easy as it was smarter than many a man he had met over the years. He dreamed of being back in the arms of his dear Princess Fina and take her as his bride. Trudging through the thick swamp made him glad he had sent Thunder back because this was no place for man or beast.

His heavy armor sank him further into the mud and soft ground than he would have liked but he tried to be as careful with his steps as he could. The paladin was being to question if his future Father-in-law had sent him here to die. There were many people far better suited for swamp travel and fighting then him yet Sir Garrett who had little experience if any experience in the swamp had been the one King Emeril had sent against the evil.

If he was optimistic in his thoughts it could be that the enemy he faced was one he was good at dispatching but the rumors of what was lurking out here had been very vague. Even rumors usually gave some hint of what sort of dangers were to be faced like if it was magic or mundane but in his rush to complete the quest he hadn’t bothered to ask vital questions. He reached out with a prayer to see if the gods could guide him in this quest.

Evil filled his senses but that was to be expected considering where he was. A dark empire had been here thousands of years ago and they had filled the ground with blood and sacrifices. Even all of these centuries later the ground was still stained with the evil. Sir Garrett said a prayer for the dead so they might be at rest, it was something he liked to do every time he came near this place in his travels. Perhaps in time, the evil might even fade from the land.

A pile of skulls looked promising to him for what he was looking for. He drew his blade and approached the bones with caution for what might be lurking nearby. This could be something old or new and wouldn’t know until he got closer. Some of the lizard people liked to mark their grounds with the bones of their enemies. If the skulls were mostly of lizardmen it would be a mark but if it was a heavy variety of sentient races it was likely old. All were slaves the Empire of the Titans, beings feared even by the gods. The world had been scarred by the battle that ended the reign of those powerful beings. If one of them was the cause of the trouble it would be a problem beyond the ability of a single paladin to stop. He shuddered at the thought as he approached the marker.
1133.title: Take the quick path through the swamp

114.content:
Sir Garrett was dedicated to the cause of good first and Princess Fina second, so when he saw a woman stumble out of the woods clutching two children desperately he knew the marriage to his love had likely been delayed. The woman spotted him and fell to her knees in thanks to the gods for bringing help to her.

"My town is being attacked by giants," the woman pleaded. "We need your help Sir Knight."

Sir Garrett wanted to comfort the woman but he felt awkward with people. His training and duty left him with little time to socialize much less make friends. When he came on scene people were usually at their worst, desperate with fear or anger at the losses that had occurred to them. Sir Garrett avoided comforting people because it was easier and simpler for him to resolve the problem at hand than try to use skills he had never learned. With that thought in mind Sir Garrett spurred Thunder to a gallop and headed in the direction the woman had come from.

It didn't take long to reach the town in question and spotting the twelve to fifteen foot giants was certainly easy. Three giants encircled the town laughing as they toyed with the villagers while a female giant with the garments of a priestess watched in what appeared to be disapproval on a nearby hill. Sir Garrett didn't take time to contemplate things as he drew a lance and launched Thunder into full speed.

The first giant didn't realize the paladin was present until he felt the sting of a lance sending him sprawling to the ground. Pain and disorientation froze the giant as the hero spun his horse and charged and used to end the threat the giant posed. To his delight the other two attacking giants roared in outrage and charged for him which left the villagers with the opportunity to escape. Sir Garrett as he charged with his third and final lance at the closer giant who left himself open in order to strike the puny human struck the behemoth in the heart but not before the giant struck back.

The paladin was launch through the air by the dying giant’s club. There was no soft landing as Sir Garrett crashed through a roof and floor before having the root cellar’s hard dirt floor break his fall. Time to heal was not a luxury that Sir Garrett had, so with his remaining strength he call upon the god Rabin, god of justice and good to heal him. The warm energy flowed through him allowing him to once again take the field of battle once more.
A search for the giant slayer was underway by the final attacking giant. It muttered curses and threats in giant as it pursued the human who had slain its companions, and to the giant’s shock the human ran from the building where it had land and darted between the giant’s legs and with both hands swung his sword cleaving the Achilles tendon causing the giant to collapse to the paved town streets.

“I curse you armored fool,” the giant bellowed in common. “I will your villages crushed beneath my feet you insect."

“Not in your lifetime,” Sir Garrett slashed the giant’s falling fist as he leapt aside from the threat.

Precision slices from the master swordsman slew the giant but it was a slow painful work. As the giant succumbed to his wounds Sir Garrett whistled for the Thunder as he prepared to check out the last giant. With reluctance Sir Garrett rode towards the last giant realizing he was about at the end of what his strength and skills would allow him to do.

The giantess was attractive with gray skin like the stone they claim to be carved from. Her body was shapely and the dress she wore clung to her curves in an appealing manner. To the delight of the weary paladin she made no hostile movement and instead stared at the warrior with fascination.

“You have the spirit of the titans,” She said with admiration. “I need your aid to take the giants from the clutches of my uncle dark rule.”

“I am afraid I have a quest I am on already,” Sir Garrett responded.
114.title: Get detoured

1141.content:
“I am afraid I can’t accept that as an answer,” the fierce blue eyes flashed as she started to cast a spell.

Sir Garrett charged at her but the distance was too great and the spell struck home, but to his surprise it didn’t appear to be an attack spell. He looked at the giant and saw she had fallen to her knees with her effort she had spent which made him wonder what kind of spell she had cast. If it was some sort of geas upon him and what it would involve, but he found the spell had actually had another purpose. The buildings and people around him started to shrink as he grew to the size of the giant.

“What have you done to me?” Sir Garrett bellowed at the giantess as he saw his horse was now a tiny figure at his feet.

“My name is Lady Brana,” she looked him in the eyes. “I promise to undue what I have done to you but I am desperate for help. The giants are going to war with the little people of the world if you don’t help me put a stop to this.”

“I guess I have little choice in the matter,” Sir Garrett growled. “Lead the way.”
1141.title: She casts a spell

11411.content:
Sir Garrett travel uneasily following Lady Brana, because he felt awkward with his new size, but he was determined to be ready when the time for combat came. He was thankful his equipment and weapons had grown with him because the equipment of the giants was unfamiliar to him. He had to admit the figure of Lady Brana was pleasing to the eye to look at as she walked ahead of him, but he wanted to be back in the capital with Princess Fina as soon as possible.

“A terrible fomorian has come from beneath the earth and is calling on the giants of frost to make war so they can have a kingdom of their own,” Lady Brana told him of the dangers. “He has dark magic he can call upon that has inspired many in the kingdom to follow him. If you were to challenge him to combat and defeat him his evil would soon leave the kingdom.”

“I fear it is not as simple as that,” Sir Garrett responded. “He may not accept my challenge.”

She turned and looked offended, “He is a giant in the lands of the frozen tundra. He would be honor bound to accept any challenge made to him.”

The paladin loved honorable combat, but he had experienced enough in his travels to know not all felt the same way as this woman. The fomorian were an evil group of giants who would give much to gain victory over an enemy even if it wasn’t honorable, and who knew what evil entity this creature had bound himself to in order to gain his dark magic. Sir Garrett had fought a fomorian before and many in his group had not long survived the encounter. The dark giants loved curses and often attached death curses to themselves as a last spite against the world. He was not looking forward to facing the creature alone.

“The fomorian do not believe in honor like the giants of ice do,” Sir Garrett explained. “He will likely try to appoint a champion to fight for him at first, most likely the greatest warrior around who he will have bound to obey him like a slave. If I am victorious he will try to use his evil magic against me in some form or fashion to remain in your lands.”

“He has promised that he respects our ways, surely he won’t betray that trust!?!”

“I have yet to hear of a fomorian who wouldn’t betray anything if it got them what they wanted.”

Her face looked troubled by this news but their was little he could tell her that would comfort her that would be the truth. Sir Garrett was by no means certain of victory against this monster but he would fight him with everything he could. If this foul creature could gather an army of frost giants thousands could die if he did nothing. He wished he could summon help to assist him but he doubted help would come in time because the longer they waited to stop the fomorian the longer he would have to bind the other giants to his will.
11411.title: Brana explains the threat

choices: Try sneaking into the frost giant territory
Send a message to the frost giants
114112.content:
As they were talking several ogres came out from behind rocks and launched themselves at the pair of giants in front of them, but Sir Garrett intercepted them with a slash from his blade killing two of them. The swing of the third’s club struck hard into the shield of the paladin, but it felt like the swing of a child with his new found size and strength. Determined to end the attack quickly he swung his blade into the throat of the third ending it’s threat.

Several orc bowmen watched from a nearby hill in shock as they debated what to do next. Sir Garrett expect that they had been told to target the female giant, and some if not all her companions would be working with them. The orcs fled the sight of an angry giant charging towards them, not willing to risk fighting an extremely powerful armored giant. Deciding to test his new strength he lifted a boulder and threw it crushing several of the orcs.

“I don’t think I got all of them,” Sir Garrett said. “We have some witnesses that this ambush failed. We need to get off this path, and come up with a plan.”
114112.title: Ambushed on the trail

1141121.content:
“I know of someone who can help us but she is many days travel from here even at the size of a giant,” Sir Garrett said. “Are you willing to take this risky quest? I believe we can help your people if we undertake the journey.”

Lady Brana pondered what the human had said to her, “Yes, I will place my trust in you.”

“We are going to free the Queen of Ice.”

The eyes of the frost giant widen at the words because she had thought the ancient dragon of ice had died long ago. It had been a terror to the people of the north with a fearsome appetite for the flesh of frost giants. She remembered shuddering at the tales her Grandmother would tell her, it had been a long time before she could stop herself from racing to obey the commands of her parents when they warned her the Queen of Ice would come for her if she failed to do as they ordered. She had eventually come to the mind that it was a legend from long in the past, but this human was telling her there was a great deal of truth to the legend.

“You would free my people by having them killed!?!” Brana asked, the fury starting to rise in her.

“We will make a deal with the creature,” Sir Garrett explained. “She was trapped by my order over a thousand years ago. She may even be dead, but a dragon with that much power doesn’t die quietly in a cave. If she is dead we can collect from her treasury enough money to pay several armies to free your people from the danger they are facing.”

She was still very frightened by the idea of the Queen of Ice being freed but she nodded her acceptance of the idea. They could at least look to see what had happened to that creature of legend. She wondered about the treasure the creature had collected over the centuries. It might be possible to collect some long lost artifacts of her people from the dragon’s treasure. If she did it would make her a hero of her people, but dark thoughts enter her head as well.

The Queen of Ice was an easy target on paper but the truth was likely to be far different. This creature probably had the intelligence and cunning of centuries and dragons were known to grow stronger with age, not weaker. What secrets of magic lurked within the lair of this legendary monster, only the confidence of the paladin helped to calm her fears.

He was handsome for a human, and he was much kinder and more gentle than the male frost giants she had known who only seemed to be concerned with their battle prowess and not what the good they could do with it. Sir Garrett often talked about the good he wanted to do for his people, and the peaceful future he was working towards. She was afraid she was starting to like him more than she should.
1141121.title: Try to get an ally

11411211.content:
It felt strange to not start a fire against the cold this far north. He knew that he was a frost giant, a creature who didn’t feel the cold as most do, but he was still tempted to make a fire because of his survival instinct. He missed the noises and the light it gave off of it. Not having a fire made home seem much further away. Sir Garrett looked at the sky and wondered what Princess Fina was thinking about, was she thinking of him, he wondered.

“What is your life like?” Brana asked him as she pulled out some food for them to eat.

“It is filled with travel and combat,” Sir Garrett responded. “There always seems to be some sort of threat to the safety of the kingdom that I must go and face. It makes me worry I won’t be able to give the Princess a happy life. A husband should be home with his wife more than a few days every couple of months. I was on my last quest for the King, and when I was done I would ask for his daughter’s hand in marriage. You interrupted that but when I am done I hope I can do good closer to home.”

“What sort of woman is this Princess Fina? In frost giant society the man and woman are welcome to travel with each other. We are often travelers across the land. Perhaps you need to find a woman who shares your interest in combating the forces of evil.”

“She is a lovely woman who sees the beauty in things and hopes for better for the future. She is playful though a little impulsive at times. Fina knows her mind and is difficult to argue against. She has great plans for the Kingdom, and she wants me to be a part of them.”

The frost giant had a little regret asking about the princess because it looked like the paladin was in love with the woman, but she decided it was a foolish and blind love. He needed someone who could travel with him and take more of a hands-on approach to making the world a better place. She would have to think of some way to convince him that he needed to look somewhere else for love.

“It is good to see you have love,” Brana said after a few minutes of thought. “It is something I think most beings look for and I hope to have myself one day. The night grows late and we should get some sleep become we have to get up in the morning and go to face the Queen of Ice. We should be at our best when we face a legend.”

Sir Garrett nodded and curled up on the ground wondering what sort of challenges they would face the next day. He was aware of the location of the feared dragon, but he had little idea of how it was guarded or what bound the dragon to the location. He didn’t want to fail because he was starting to care about Brana and by extension her people. Maybe they could be allies one day.
11411211.title: Talk before bed

choices: What do I have to offer you for this honor
114112111.content:
Brana had awakened before Sir Garrett and investigated the spot where she had been the entrance was and started to work on clearing the entrance. Things would be simpler if Princess Fina was a frost giant as well. She could declare her attentions for Sir Garrett and fight her in a form of combat that the Princess chose. Brana was certain she could best the pampered Princess in any challenge the spoiled royal could come up with.

Working up some sweat felt good and helped relax her mind. A thought came to mind and she came up with a plan on how to win the heart of the paladin. She had made him a giant, why couldn’t she transform into a human when this quest was completed so she could challenge the Princess. It would be unfair to transform the untrained girl into a frost giant to face her so she would take on the awkward form of a human girl to face Princess Fina and still win and earn the even greater honor.

“You are doing some fine work,” Sir Garrett walked up and started moving stones aside. “You could have woke me up to come help with this.”

She smiled at him, “I know but I am a hard worker and I have already burdened you with so much during this quest, this is the least I could do.”

“Don’t worry about burdening me with this quest because it is a worthy one. Perhaps we will be able to form an alliance between your people and mine.”

A blush formed on her cheeks as she thought about forming a marriage alliance with him for the good of her people. It made her happy but she shook the thought from her head and got back to work. She wanted to challenge this Princess properly and not just earn his love through the political goals for the future.

They stopped in their work when they formed a small hole, well small hole for a frost Giant for them to crawl through. Sir Garrett drew his blade and crawled through first but followed closely by Brana who lit the room with a bright white orb that floated in front of them lighting the path. A dull glow of red showed in the many arcane symbols carved into the icy walls indicating magic still worked to entrapped the monster they were about to face.

The tunnel opened into a gigantic chamber with a large pit in the center of the room filled with golden treasure though more than a small portion of it was covered by a white dragon of legendary size. Shallow breathing could be seen as the chest expanded and shrank as the creature seemed to take little notice of their presence but Sir Garrett wasn’t taking any chances and lifted his shield up into a protective position and slapped his blade against the shield creating an echoing sound through the chamber. An eyelid lifted slowly revealing a glowing white orb that eyed the intruders to its chamber.

“Have you come to try and kill me?” the Queen of Ice asked. There was no fear in the voice, only a sense of boredom. “Even in my starved state, I am more than a match for a couple of frost giant.”

“We have come to bargain with you wyrm,” Sir Garrett tried to say with confidence. He could feel Brana’s fear drawn from generations of death this creature had inflicted on her people but she managed to contain it to a slight shudder.

The head of the monster lifted as interest began to fill the dragon, “What would you have me do to earn my freedom?”

Brana called out, “I wish you to slay the foul Fomorian who is corrupting my people, do we have a deal?”

Laughter shook the chamber as the beast chuckled at the words of the frost giant. Shards of glass shattered as they hit the floor before a fearsome grin formed on the face of the monster. Sir Garrett wasn’t sure what to make of the creature’s amusement. It had no doubt heard of the evil giant race but what did it think of them? Dragons generally hated giants but maybe it was different for this dragon. He doubted it was afraid because few things scared a dragon of this size the only thing they generally feared was a larger dragon.
114112111.title: The entrance is buried

1141121113.content:
“A Fomorian you say,” the creature mulled this over in its mind. “What conditions would you place on me for this honor?”

Sir Garrett and Brana stood stunned for a moment as they tried to figure out if the creature was trying to trick them but the creature seemed completely serious about being willing to offer more for the honor to slay the giant. The paladin decided to test the monster to see if it was serious about what it was saying and make it take a sacred oath on its treasure. Few dragons, even those of the evilest nature would break an oath taken upon their hoard.

“You will not attack the people of the north including the frost giants,” Sir Garrett spoke up. “Swear upon your hoard.”

“I am willing if the condition that I have the right to defend myself if I am attacked,” the Queen of Ice responded. “It is no great sacrifice as humans are too small to be satisfying and frost giants have a terrible aftertaste to them.”

Brana started to protest the taste of frost giants but Sir Garrett waved her down because it seemed like they had gotten what they wanted, there was no need to argue. He suspected the dragon was having some fun at the expense of the Frost Giant. She hesitated a moment but saw the wisdom of holding back.

“Agreed,” Sir Garrett answered. “Why are you so willing to make a deal with us?”

“Revenge is almost as delicious as a treasure to a dragon. Your order deals with holy magic, surely you have noticed the arcane and foul nature of the magic that binds me. This Fomorian may not be the one who has done this to me but I plan for it to be the first of many I devour. The extinction of the race is my next goal in life.”

“That is suicidal. They are too many and too powerful for any creature to stand against them,” Brana said.

“For a giant-sized creature you have small ideas,” the dragon retorted. “They are their own worst enemies. I will be hired to kill many of them before they even realize what is going on and I shall take in treasure that will make what I have like a pittance. The treasure can fund the destruction of the rest of the disgusting creature. It is a simple plan but with my power, it will be most effective.”

“I can’t say I agree with your motives but I applaud your cause,” Sir Garrett encouraged.

“Who am I to deny you the honor of dying in combat,” Brana said.

“How very kind of you but I intend to make others do the dying so start breaking these enchantments so I can get started,” the Queen of Ice demanded.

Sir Garrett and Brana started their work and debated about how to approach attacking the Fomorian. Thankfully, the work was easy as the enchantment’s powers had faded over the years so they had plenty of time to talk.
1141121113.title: What do I have to offer you for this honor

11411211132.content:
“We have to make sure you are successful,” Sir Garrett told the dragon. “I will challenge the champion which will draw all of the attention and focus to me so you can attack the Fomorian, giving you a chance to kill the foul thing without it having a lot of bodyguards to use against you.”

“Aren’t you sweet, unnecessary, but sweet,” the dragon was stretching her wings and moving muscles that had been locked down by magic for centuries. “It shall give me a chance to explore how this land has changed.”

Brana suspected the great monster had left off that it would be exploring what it considered was its territory. She hoped she could convince her people to avoid the dragon but the frost giants were always looking for strong opponents to face. The bargain they had made with it was of no great burden on it because her people would happily attack it so they could face an honorable death. She wondered how many of her people would soon be trophies themselves but at least it would be a death of their choosing instead of death as slaves to the Fomorian.

“It is likely you will be made to face the best of my people,”Brana's face showed great concern as she warned the paladin. “He will likely be enhanced with the dark magic of the Fomorian, I don’t know if you can win and I don’t know if the fight will stop even with the arrival of the dragon. Frost Giants believe strongly in ritual combat and once started, if it is a battle to the death, it will not end until one of you is dead.”

“I guess I will just have to win,” Sir Garrett gave her a warm smile. “What shall I challenge them about?”

“It will have to be something that challenges the authority of Narzoc, he will likely sense it is a trap but if it is something important he will have to step into it even if he sees the danger you present. You could go for the leadership of the tribe.”

“I think it would be better if I challenged for your hand in marriage, it would draw a lot more attention to have an outsider to come seeking the hand of a frost giant than one of an endless stream of challengers seeking power. What do you think?”

“I would be okay with you marrying me.”

The paladin could spy the village just ahead so didn’t really hear her words or see the look on her face. She was very pleased with the thought of marrying him, she knew he had a fiancee and his intention was to marry that would but he was a man of honor, if the marriage happened he would be devoted to it and she would show him that he made the right choice. She quickly brushed aside the idea of tricking him into marrying her, it would go against her honor, she wouldn’t want him that way, but she didn’t know how hard she would fight if they were pushed in the direction of marriage.

“Who dares to come to try and enter the village of Frosted Meadows?” a frost giant carrying an intricately designed war hammer stepped towards them when they drew close to the entrance of the village.

“I am Sir Garrett of the Order of the Silver Griffin and I have come to take up Brana’s hand in marriage,” Sir Garrett lifted Brana’s hand and held it tight. “She wishes for the Chieftain of your tribe to perform the marriage ceremony.”

The sneer on the face of the man was instantaneous, “Silver Griffin, that means that you are a human! There is no way we can allow this to stand, Narzoc will have something to say about this.”

“I will challenge him and anyone else who dares to deny the love I have for her!”

More Frost Giants were gathering as his words reached them and most importantly the Fomorian made his appearance. The creature hobbled along clutching a staff with both hands but the paladin knew it was an act, if he were truly that weak he would have been killed long ago. It had hideous purple skin covered in warts and moles, the telltale sign of the Fomorian an oversized yellow eye kept a close watch on the holy warrior, a look filled with hate. These dark creatures knew an enemy when they saw one.

“So a foul human seeks to pervert the noble lineage of the frost giants, let’s see how strong your love truly is,” Narzoc pointed a gnarled and twisted finger at Sir Garrett.
11411211132.title: Act as a Distraction

114112111321.content:
Narzoc’s baleful eye flitted about seeming to see nothing and yet it saw everything. A malicious grin formed on the hideous face. A dark plan had come to the evil creature.

“I am fine with you marrying her,” his hand waved the cries of protest to silence. “If you can beat a champion of my choosing. Said champion will take her hand should you lose.”

Buy time and keep him busy, Sir Garrett reminded himself, “I would see this champion first because I have heard of the deceptions of the Fomorian.”

“Certainly, I have always kept my word to this noble tribe.”

He motioned and a giant stepped from the crowd. Brana winced at the appearance of the frost giant. It was clear he was small by frost giant standards and his face looked malformed by something other than combat. The leer on his face was clear as his eyes never her bosom.

“Runark shall fight you,” Narzoc smile. “He looks forward to your wedding night Brana. He has been most explicit.”

“I shall fight him,” Sir Garrett’s eyes searched the sky but he could still see nothing. How long did a frost giant wedding last? Because he felt he would make short work of his opponent.

A circle started to form as they prepared for battle. They might not be happy about their princess marrying the lodge’s shaman but it was no reason to not enjoy a fight. Betting was heavy with even the Fomorian not missing the chance to place a bet.

“You appear to be under an enchantment,” Narzoc quickly cast his magic. “We do want this to be a fair fight.”

The paladin was dwarfed by the giants a moment later. Even his opponent was nearly three times his size now. Many of the frost giants roared in protest at the Fomorian changing the odds but the monster just laughed at them. He would be pleased with taking their money but Sir Garrett had no intention of giving up this fight. The holy warrior was determined to make his enemy lose a fortune though he wouldn’t be sad if the white dragon arrived before than.

“Ready to die little man?” Runark bellowed.

“You can do this,” Brana took off her coin pouch. “Sir Garrett to win.”

“I would hate to lose your money,” he smiled warmly at her before dropping his faceplate down. “Guess I am going to have to win.”

Sir Garrett prayed, calling upon the gods and they answered him. They were always up for a good fight and he started to glow with their blessing. The crowd roared their approval as he charged forward.

Runark swung his mighty hammer but his accuracy was off by a hair’s breadth. The shock wave sent the paladin into the air. He slashed with divine power to enhance his strike. There was a terrible cry of pain as it cut through to the bone. The arm would be nearly useless but there was no way he was stopping there.

A stomp of the foot or a smash could still very easily end him. Sir Garrett charged forward to stab his shield into the foot of his opponent giving the frost giant more to worry about.

“I will crush you!” Runark howled as he danced around trying to crush the paladin.

It was dangerous around the feet but it was awkward for the frost giant to see him. He slashed carefully because if his blade got stuck he was likely doomed. A few good cuts and a giant could no longer support the massive amount of weight. His chance came as the thick boot came apart. With both feet firmly planted he lunged forward severing the precious tendon. Sir Garrett pulled back from the flailing giant and allowed himself a moment to breathe.

The giant struggled to regain himself but the holy warrior wasn’t about to let that happen. As Runark sat up his gaze came upon Sir Garrett flying through the air towards him. A gush of blood came from the throat from the fatal wound an instant later.

“Sir Garrett is the winner!” Brana cheered and many of the other frost giants joined their voices to her. More than a few were happy to have a victory over the Fomorian.

A sour look had formed on Narzoc’s face though it was hard to tell on the hideous features. He was certain to not let this loss last for wrong. Sir Garrett hoped the dragon would arrive before he had to face a dozen frost giants and in angry Fomorian.
114112111321.title: Dispel Magic

1142.content:
“My name is Brana and I need your help, please,” Brana got on her knees as tears welled in her eyes.

Sir Garrett hated to see a woman cry even a frost giantess but he wanted to complete the quest so he could get back to his Princess and this would be a further delay. He wanted to tell her this was an order from his King but he had never seen a giant look so vulnerable. Perhaps he did have the time to assist her. Improving relations with the frost giants would improve things in the north of the kingdom and if they could get a peace treaty he knew of a lot of communities that would thank him.

“I know how much pride your people have so I know how grand a gesture this is,” Sir Garrett motioned for her to stand. “I will go with you and assist you in whatever way I can.”

Her warm smile made him happy with his choice though he was certain he was likely to regret it later. Frost Giants were powerful warriors who lived for combat and he was less than half their size. A duel with one was likely to be foolish and a battle with more than one became far more dangerous for his health but he did have a few advantages against them. They were arrogant, and would likely underestimate one of his size. Frost giants had rarely encountered knights in armor on a horse so they would be unfamiliar with his style of combat or how deadly the lance could be against them, most would think it was a sharpened stick and laugh at his efforts with it.

“Do you think I can challenge your Uncle to a duel and be done with this with as little bloodshed as possible?” Sir Garrett asked.

“It might be, my Uncle is a coward who hides behind his champion Bruga,” Brana explained. “He plans to marry me to the brute in exchange for his loyalty but like most of my people, he views humans as weak. He might be willing to fight you to inspire the others to march on your Kingdom.”

“I hope you are right. Things are likely to go very bad if you are wrong. Let’s get started because we have a lot of road ahead of us if your land is where I think it is.”

“We live far to the north on the Spiky Peaks Iceberg.”

The news got better and better, the place she spoke of was a fortress in the middle of a patch of icy deadly waters. Her clan was known for the ruthless raiders they produced who made life miserable for many a shipping merchant. Most giants liked to intimidate those who were smaller than them but she was dealing with him honestly. If he ended up helping her, it was going to take a lot more time because her people were north and he was heading south.

He waved goodbye to her and set about continuing his quest for the King. Perhaps he would find there was nothing wrong in the swamps and be able to help her shortly but he doubted it.

The sun was growing intense on his metal armor but he pressed on, feeling a new urgency to complete the task. Trees started to grow thicker as he closed the distance to the swamp. He came to the top of a hill and looked over the expanse of the Dread Swamp. The land had reclaimed all of the city that had once been there. Greenery had covered the ruins so only the occasional lump could be seen in the sea of green. Many an adventurer went in to seek their fortune from the remnants of the ancient kingdom but Sir Garrett had heard of few ever returning from the location. Like many places rumored to have a great treasure there was was more death than treasure but the deaths only seemed to grow the legends.

Last Hope was at the bottom of the hill just before the swamps began in earnest. It was a place where many dangerous beings met to trade. It would be a good place to stop to get the information he needed but his presence was certain to not be welcomed by the residents. Griffins were intelligent animals whose talons and swift flight on eagle wings made them apex predators few people with any sense had any contact with. Training for the animals was a long and difficult process that often took years, and was usually hopeless if it wasn’t raised from a young age by experienced trainers. Thankfully, Sir Garrett could call upon his connection with the heavens to bond him with an adult animal and make it his sacred mount.

Sir Garrett smiled at the last thought and wondered if he would be able to retire from being a paladin. It was likely there would always be a mission beckoning him to do good in the world, and Sir Garrett said a small prayer Princess Fina and any children he had would have years of his company before the forces of darkness ended his fight.

Mount Titan was a known roust for griffins, so it was here Sir Garrett had headed in his quest. As the noble warrior reached the base of the mountain he sent Thunder home while saying a small prayer for his safety for griffins had a taste for horse flesh. There seemed to be two trails up the mountain. The first was larger and likely been built by worshippers of the titans who been locked away by the gods long ago, and the second was a smaller perilous trail which was likely used by locals to collect bird eggs. The people that worked the mountain truly earned their keep.

He came around the bend in the trail to discover a small group of guards stepped forward into his path. They wore symbols that he didn’t recognize but it was obvious that they were a unified force who had no intention of allowing him to move any further along the path but he had no intention to be stopped without good cause.

“I have reason to head up the mountain and need to pass,” Sir Garrett resisted the urge to draw his blade despite them having their swords at the ready. They may have been part of an organized force but their movement betrayed their inexperience. He could see how nervous they were against him even though they out numbered him five to one. There was a tremble to their blades that told they were frightened of him.

“No one is going up the mountain this week,” a calmer man stepped forward with an air of some authority calming the others. “We are doing some trail work to clear, you can come up here next week when the work is done.”

The words seemed reasonable but there was a hint of dishonesty to what the man said. He didn’t recognize their uniforms and he didn’t know of any of the local nobles who cared enough about the safety of their peasants to take care of the trails. It was tempting to let this pass and continue on his journey but lies didn’t sit well with him. These people were likely up to things they shouldn’t be and if they were doing wrong he would put a stop to them even if he was out numbered.

But then again, that was something to be expected, right? Sir Garret suddenly realized he was being far, far too foolish, especially against a man he realized meant him no harm and was being particularly friendly and welcoming. The knight blinked a few times before sliding his sword back into it's scabbard and pulled himself out of his combat stance.

"There, was that so hard?" The man's voice was normal again as he lowered his hand.

"My apologies, friend" Garret said, and he truly meant it, "My training and the urgency of my quest have left me on edge. I respect your own duties, but I simply must get through!"

The man frowned for a moment and Garret felt the tension rise once more, before his potential foe smiled and waved his hands to either side of him, his men immediately releasing their grips on their own swords and backing away.

"Well then, if a knight requests it, so shall it be done! Take heed, however, the path is quite treacherous. Allow me to escort you through the sections of trail we have already cleared out." The man raised his hand again. "My I have your name, friend?"

The man's invitation seemed quite civil, and Garret felt no ill-intent behind the words. After all, this man had done nothing to present himself as anything other than friendly. Sir Garret nodded and made his way across the short distance separating him from the group of men, reaching them in moments and extending his armored hand towards the speaker. "My name is Sir Garret, might I have yours?"

The man's hand remained raised as he brought his other up to shake Garret's hand, "You don't need me to tell you my name, we've been friends for years! Now come, let us journey together, and let me keep you safe before that fool head of yours gets you into trouble" Again the man's voice shifted and wavered in tone and pitch.

Sir Garret blinked a few more times before he felt himself nodding. Of course, this man was a dear friend of his from the heady days of youth, when they'd been but boys in the training yard! A name floated out of the sudden fog that he felt on his mind, Longhack. It was a name the man had earned from the other boys during sword training, Longhack had, on his first try, cut a training dummy in two with a longsword. Oh, Garret felt like such an idiot for forgetting!

Maybe it was just the altitude and the weather, but Garret, even in the company of his old friend, couldn't help feeling overly befuddled at the current chain of events, like the fog in his mind was growing denser with each passing moment. The creature was so focused on the target it didn’t notice the rope until it was too late. The creature gave a deafening shriek as it tried to fly away taking the paladin with it and the villager looked on in shock as Sir Garrett soared past her.

Gusts of wind smashed into the paladin from the powerful animal as he held on for dear life. He wasn’t sure he had the right animal because this seemed more difficult than it should be. When he had found Thunder he had felt a connection and it had been easy. The others in the order had warned him it wouldn’t be as easy with a griffin because they were a far different animal and he would have to prove his worth to it before the creature would accept him. They had never been very specific about how it was done, only that it varied. The creature dropped in the sky so he was hitting the tree tops smashing them as his body was battered.
1152.title: Small path

1153.content:
He had brought the climbing equipment, he might as well use it. Sir Garrett removed his armor and weapons save a dagger and set about climbing the mountain. He had training in climbing but it had been many years since he felt truly proficient in the skill but the animal he was hunting respected the effort that climbing took or the Griffin might just decide it was hungry and eat him.

His dagger and skills would make him a tough prey for the creatures but he hoped it wouldn’t come to that. Sweat poured down his face as he climbed the mountain pulling his heavy frame up the mountain. Every few minutes he stopped and checked the sky for any Griffins looking for easy prey or a master who would ride them to complete a noble quest. He didn’t know how an animal who would be his bonded mount would look but he certainly hoped they would recognize each other.

The glare from something bright flashed his eyes and he realized it was a griffin, a silver one. The creature looked like it had been carved from the medal and he was certain this was the one he was looking for the question plaguing his mind was how would he reach it. Getting to a stable ledge he whistled the Griffin hoping that it would come to him but the animal seemed to take no note of the noise he was making. All he felt he could do was to continue climbing and hope it came down for a closer look.

A great chill started to shake his body as he got closer to the peak of the mountain as he followed the animal to where it had vanished over the top of the plateau. He took a look around as his body started to relax from his efforts.
1153.title: Scale the Mountain

11531.content:
As he took a break he looked at the world around him and was reminded of the beauty of the world around him as he could see far over the Kingdom of Dar. Small villages dotted the land between great stretches of forests and swamps, streams of smoke gave signs of life and activity. Everything looked peaceful and tranquil and gave him a great that all would be well with the world, unfortunately, reality started to set in for him as he looked down the mountain and saw a yeti climbing up after him.

The hairy beast seemed to smile a fang-filled mouth at him as it was observed as if he could do nothing about it. Admittedly, he would have felt much better fighting the monster on solid ground under his feet and his armor protecting his body but even on the creature’s home turf, he was far from helpless. His eyes took greater notice of the mountain as he searched for the best place to do battle from instead of the best way up the mountain.

It was tempting to throw the dagger but it was better to keep that for if the fighting got close and personal which he planned to do his best to avoid. The monster was stronger than him physically and only a fool went into a battle for survival at a disadvantage. There were some loose rocks he could use as projectiles and he hoped his rock throwing as a child would pay off with the death of the creature this day.

He waited for the creature to start another reaching grasp and threw striking the hand bruising the hand but kept a grip on the mountain. It let loose a defiant roar at him but he responded with a heavy rock dropped on the head of the monster. This time the noise was a howl of pain, blood poured into the vision of the yeti, it tried to wipe the blood away.

Sir Garrett jumped down on the creature as it was trying to regain the eyesight it had momentarily lost. It was a risky move and he knew it but prepared himself the best he could. His body weight was intensified by gravity slamming him into the monster sending it tumbling from the mountain, its home had become death to it. The rocks were unforgiving to the longtime resident as they were to any newcomer to the mountain and it wasn’t long before the lifeless corpse of the yeti was added to the mountain’s growing number of dead.

The paladin did not escape unscathed as the rope he had tethered himself with to the mountain grew taunt and yanked him back to the cliff side in a jolting hit. His body was sore already from his exertions, he summoned the healing into his body and started the climb up the mountain again hoping he wouldn’t have to face any more of the foul yetis. He was nearly at the peak but he wasn’t entirely sure what he would find.
11531.title: A yeti stalks towards him

choices: Seek out a companion to assist you
Take the main road to face Dreze
Use the hidden portal to get behind enemy lines
Use your flying carpet to head out
12.content:
Marina had been studying the mystical arts for over a century but appeared no older than her early twenties. Life had been kind to Marina giving her beauty and a mind that found magic easy to master, so she began to find life sacred which is why she founded the Circle of the Enlightened. It was a collection of wizards dedicated to using magic to solve problems without killing. Helping the King would provide an excellent chance to prove the success of the Circle of the Enlightened. She had already decided to take on the might of the wizard Dreze as an added bonus of ridding the land of her evil former master.

Marina tied her long chestnut hair back and gathered items to use on her journey. She hated to drain the magic from so many items she had spent so long building and spending many a gold coin for ingrediants, but using items would conserve her energy for the fearsome battle she would have against Dreze when the time came. Marina gathered her various rings of changes and placing her necklace of protection around her neck. Soon she felt ready to start her journey.
12.title: Marina Mage of the Circle of Enlightened

121.content:
Marian decided it would be wisest if she didn’t travel alone on this perilous quest. It would normally be difficult to find someone who shared her views to travel with but luckily a cleric of the holy light who she knew well was in town. Timothy Black was an excellent travel companion, but he might have duties which prevented him from coming on the journey.

Timothy Black believed firmly in the sanctity of life, and worked to make the world better by freeing people from curses and binding ancient evils to prevent them from harming civilization. He was a physically imposing man with dark hair and darker eyes. A flail hung at his side awaiting use against opponents who didn’t respect his words or his magic.

“What brings you by Marian?” Timothy wiped the sweat from his brow as he stopped his gardening.

“I am looking for help to take down Dreze,” Marian answered.

Timothy frowned, “It will take a lot of work and death will likely be involved. Are you prepared for that?”

“With my skill and your assistance I am hoping to avoid any killings.”

“But are you prepared to kill if it has to be done.”

Marina paused a moment as she thought about it, “If Dreze or one of his minions has to be killed, but I am willing to risk a lot to prevent that from happening.”

“Good, as long as that is understood I am willing to help you,” Timothy responded. “I am willing to give up many pieces of my humanity to end an evil like Dreze.”

It didn’t take long for the cleric to prepare himself for the journey. Having a wizard along who could conjure food and supplies made packing easier. The only thing left to decide was what path to take.
121.title: Seek out a companion to assist you

1211.content:
“I suggest we go through the mountain pass,” Timothy spoke up.

Marina nodded at the wisdom of the idea because the pass would allow them to get around the army of Dreze. It was too difficult to move an army through the narrow hazardous trails in the mountains. Dreze would want to travel by water or over the paved roads of this land to keep his soldiers from worn down from the travel. Two travels could make it through the mountains but even they would have to be careful because of the dangers of the hill giant tribe that stalked the mountains.

They were slow-witted creatures who were a greedy and gluttonous creature with great physical strength. Hill giants loved picking on creatures smaller than them and at over ten feet tall in height most creatures were dwarfed by them. A tribe of them had recently been preying on those who traveled the trails through the mountain.

Marina wore a lot of clear signs that she was a magic user because the foul smelling creatures fear magic. It was one of the few things they were vulnerable to so they usually tried to avoid any spell caster they encountered but on occasion, they tried to crush them with rocks from a distance. These mountains certainly had enough rocks for them to crush ten thousand magical users.

The Ghost Mountains were rumored to have been created in a great battle between the Gods and a Titan. All of the stones and boulders on the mountain were said to be the coagulated blood of the slain titan. All of the stones on the mountain were stained a red hue but Marina doubted there was any truth in the stories. She thought all of the violence over the years in the mountains was a more likely cause, perhaps there was a curse on the mountains from the Titan all of those ages ago that caused so many to fight in these mountains.

These mountains were named for all the ghosts that haunted the range. She had never understood why so many had fought in these mountains because there was little of value here. No crops to grow, precious metals to mine or valuable gems to collect yet great seas of life had died and washed over these rocks. She didn’t see how it was possible that large armies had done battles on these narrows passes but a rusted helmet or a broken blade reminded her of the truth of the stories.

“May the Gods grant you passage into the afterlife,” Timothy quietly stopped and whispered to some unseen presence.

“Any ghosts I should be worried about?” Marina asked nervously.

He shook his head, “Just some shades that needed help finding the path but we have to be careful because there is a lot of spiritual energy in the air from all of the ghosts. Ghosts are generally harmless but there are things that feed on them that are far from harmless. These lands are ripe for demons or devils stalking the grounds.”
1211.title: Mountain

12111.content:
The announcement of giant proportions was the landing of rock against Marina sending her tumbling backward despite the efforts of protection magic. She tried to collect herself but was having a hard time focusing on her vision.

“Gorga crush human,” a hill strode confidently towards them. The stench was powerful and the priest prayed for rain to alleviate some of the noxious odors. He was a particularly ugly specimen with a mouth slacked open with drool streaming out. The giant carried a club or rather a tree trunk with the branches knocked off swung at Timothy smashing the ground he was standing upon.

“You will have to do better than that,” Timothy’s flail lit up with divine power as he struck the hand of the giant.

The hideous creature cried out in pain releasing his grip on his weapon to suck at the fresh injury, “You hurt Gorga. Gorga hurt you.”

There was little room to dodge on the mountain. The foot of the giant struck the breastplate slamming the priest into the cliffside. He grunted in pain but was glad to not have been sent flying over the edge. Gorga paused a moment to rub his toe where it had struck the armor.

“Gorga squish you.” the giant howled.

It would have been hilarious if it weren’t so dangerous. The giant was hopping slowly forward shaking the mountain as he approached with certain death. If the tumbling rocks didn’t kill them all first. Even the giant had to swat away a few.

“Anytime you could help would be great,” he had prepared himself against undead not giants and had expected Marina to take care of larger threats. A blast of celestial fire halted the approach for a moment but he didn’t have much else to call upon.

Marina had recovered enough to cast a transformation spell. The giant changed into . . .
12111.title: Giant trouble

choices: Make it through the Kingdom safely
1212.content:
“I know of a shortcut but it would mean going through the kingdom of the Fae,” Tim told Marina. “We should be able to get in and out before they even notice we are there because the path isn’t used very often.”

Marina frowned, “How do you know a fairy path?”

“I was given it as pay back for trapping a Fae noble.”

Marina shuddered at the thought because the nobles of Fae took a great deal of joy paying back grudges and even if the creature failed to escape in the lifetime of the cleric it was likely any relatives of his would be in danger of the revenge of the creature. The Fae were notoriously difficult to trap and the servants were likely already looking for ways to get revenge or break their master free. It wasn’t often done out of love of their cruel masters, spells were placed on servants to force loyalty usually with the servant knowing they were being forced to serve someone that they hated.

“I hope your prison for the creature is well made because if it ever gets out you are almost certainly doomed,” Marina said.

Tim shrugged, “Most of my enemies are deadly that is why I have vowed to never have a family. It would put too much burden on them. There are too many creatures that want revenge against me that could break free if given millennia of time. I hope to build an order to keep those I have captured buried until they can be dealt with in a better way.”

“A noble thought. If you think this shortcut is worth the risk I will follow your lead into the kingdom of the Fae.”
1212.title: Shortcut

1213.content:
“I want to take the rapids,” Marina said. “We should be able to avoid his forces with ease and get behind them so we can strike Dreze directly.”

“The rapids are very dangerous, are you sure?” Timothy asked.

“I can use a magical boat I have crafted to get us through safely so even the most dangerous rapids are no real hazard.”

“Do you know about any hostile creatures in the area, because I haven’t heard of anyone traveling that path and if people don’t use it there is usually a very good reason.”

Marina liked working with Timothy but sometimes his careful planning could become very frustrating because he liked to plan everything out to the tiniest detail. It was usually fine but when you were dealing with an approaching army it was important to get things done when an opportunity presented itself. There wasn’t much time before the foul wizard Dreze made his way through the mountain and there would be little chance to get around him and a direct confrontation with his army would result in a great loss of life that she could do little to prevent.

“I want to do this and we don’t have much time when Dreze gets to this side of the mountains he will be able to take control of the river and how do propose to get behind his army to him then?” Marina questioned angrily.

“These are fair questions I am asking, an hour spent discussing things can prevent hours or days of delay or dangers but I will go with you and trust your judgment. If you say we need to go, we go.”

He followed her to the river where she pulled out a small wooden boat and placed it in the river. Timothy resisted the urge to comment about fitting because she had already let him know that it was magical and soon it expanded to the point that it could fit three or four people. He started to load it interested to see how it work. It didn’t appear that the boat actually rested on the water but hovered a few inches above which might allow it to ride over the dangerous rocks in the rapids.

“How long can it stay afloat like that?” Timothy said as he got aboard the boat to start the trip.

“Twelve hours and then I have to recharge it for at least an hour,” Marina answered. “I have several energy stones to use so I don’t have to use my own power.”

“Good, then what are we waiting for.”

The ride was less than pleasant as the vessel jostled and shook over the rapids but it made no signs that it was going to over turn. The gigantic mountains stood over them on either side of the river shrouding them in darkness. Timothy would be a lot happier when he was on the other side of these mountains because of how foreboding they felt.

He had always hated things that were unfamiliar to him so he had dedicated his life to knowledge. He had seen the destruction the ancient evils that lurked in the world could do so he had searched out the knowledge to stop them and put them where they could never hurt anyone again. The sound of singing came to his ears and he wondered who could be out there with such a beautiful melody.
1213.title: River

12131.content:
Marina spied the twitch of a tale in the distance, “Mermaids!”

Not much was known about the aquatic creatures who were rarely seen. There were rumors that a few of the rich and powerful kept the creatures as pets, pleasure slaves or guardians she couldn’t be certain her to wish she had studied aquatic creatures more but she had never had a desire to take any sea voyage. The song they were singing had an enchanting tone to it that made her want to relax which she quickly fought against as it felt like a form of magic.

She turned to Timothy to give him further warning to cover his ears but she saw that he was already under deeper than she was. He stepped from the boat and disappeared into the water to her horror. Whatever mermaids were they appeared to be hostile and she would have to stop them but first, she had to focus on countering their magic or she would have no way to help her friend.

Timothy knew he shouldn’t be listening to the call that was beckoning him from the boat but he hadn’t been expecting danger from the water, he had been expecting a threat from above but the waters here were so turbulent he had never suspected that anything dangerous could be living down there, it had been a mistake he would berate a rookie over.

The water was close to freezing, fresh mountain meltwater but it was surprisingly clear as he saw several mermaids swimming towards him. He had heard they were beautiful but he had never imagined them to be so colorful. They were like the tropical fish that he had seen during his studies with brilliant colors like golden scales or crimson hair. The creatures smiled warmly as the approached, the beautiful song they were singing was even more clear under the water.

He knew that he should be worried about the struggle for air but he could only enjoy the song. Before Timothy’s situation became dire the golden scaled beauty swam up to him and gave him a passionate kiss. Her tongue wandered his mouth as pleasure filled his body even with her clamped on his mouth he suddenly found himself able to breathe.

The other women started to strip his armor and clothing from his body allowing them to drop to the bottom of the river bed. He was no longer chilled by water and felt more at ease and aroused by the situation. His hands wandered her naked form gently rubbing her breasts enjoying the feeling. Timothy started to shrink in size as his muscles vanished and a webbing formed between his toes. The bliss of the kiss blinded him to the changes as he started to take on the shape of a mermaid. All signs of his manhood were gone soon gone and a beautiful pink haired mermaid with a large chest floated in the water.

Marina didn’t know how long it took her to block the spell but she knew she had a limited time left to save her friend she needed to do something fast.
12131.title: Mermaid

121311.content:
The powerful spellcaster called upon her magic but the boat shook under her feet sending her to floor banging her head hard. Her vision was blurred but she could see several mermaids giggling as they slid into the boat. She needed to fight before she joined her companion forever beneath the water. The bright golden gem on her ring of transformation flared to a blinding light before it burned out to a cold black never to be used again.

Two of the mermaids flew back from the boat as their bodies warped with the transformation. Their bikini tops fell away as they shrank revealing spectacular breasts for a brief moment before scales coated them. Hair dropped into the water below sinking beneath the surface as their heads stretched into those of simple fish losing all intelligence from the eyes. Finally, the magic released them done with the work the pair of mermaids were fish off to breed under the swift currents.

Her vision was clearing as she turned to face the last mermaid in the boat and her as her lips started the words that would end the threat they were matched by the cold wet lips of the water creature. The kiss started to warm up to an intense heat she had never experienced before. Marina tried to shove the mermaid off of her but slid off of her wet form. The claws of the monster tore open the robes of the wizard and started rubbing her breasts. Her chest started to swell as she squealed with joy as her body changed under the power of the mermaid’s kiss.

Marina knew she was changing but the feelings were so intense she ignored the danger she was facing. Her legs merged as scales replaced the soft skin of a human. Finally, her change was done and a gorgeous mermaid with long violet hair and scales was released from the kiss.

“Welcome to the sisterhood,” the golden-haired beauty told her. “We have work for you to do.”
121311.title: Change into Mermaid

1213113.content:
“You shall now be called Gali,” the mermaid caressed the tender parts of the recruit. “I am Lady Liana. I would delight in teaching you so many things but we have not the time for it my darling. We are war with your king. I have recruited you because we need your magic. Dar has been capturing our sisters for the playthings of the nobility.”

“How terrible!” Gali proclaimed. She knew she had once been a servant to King Emeril but it felt like another life, it was another life.

“We need to have the power of the Kraken to end the threat of the port of Crescent. This river will give us a way into those heavily protected waters.”

Gali frowned at the word Kraken. She knew a great deal of transformation magic but this might be beyond her. It would require a grand ritual.

“There is a lot of risks to the spell,” She warned Lady Liana. “I have read about the workings but it requires at least ten people. There are a lot of pieces I will need to craft the magic circle.”

Lady Liana smiled, “We shall get all of your needs. You tell us what you need and we shall procure it for you. Follow me with your sister Seia.”

The pink-haired beauty was her companion once again. They twirled around each other enjoying the feeling of being at being masters of the water. Their Lady laughed as she joined them a little play. The flow of the water started to ebb to a small trickle of the former glory.

The light had faded from the sky as they were forced to crawl across the stone as the water trickled over an edge into the water below. In the distance, the lanterns of Crescent were glowing. Several trading vessels sat docked as a couple of warships patrolled the harbor.

“Time to dive in!” Lady Liana jumped off into the dark water below and the other two quickly followed her.
1213113.title: Infiltration

122.content:
Marina decided to take the main road to the lands Dreze controlled because it would be easy travel and Dreze would likely expect travel by magic. Traveling on the road as a pilgrim gave her a chance to see the refugees fleeing the ravages of Dreze’s army. Few took notice of her as they were caught up in their own worries to take notice of anyone who wasn’t a threat. As soon as she passed from the sight Marina vanished from their minds replaced by the more real needs for food and shelter.

As Marina drew close to the advances of Dreze’s army she decided to pull off into the woods and come up with a disguise. Luckily a master of transformation magic has an easy time coming up with a disguise. She thought about becoming a horse at first because they were a common sight but too many people would try to catch her, so she decided to become a deer. A wood be able to maneuver the woods with ease and hunters would be few with an army on the march.

Her cloths and items vanished as Marina cast her spell leaving her naked to the night air. Sweat poured down her breasts as her heart raced to carry out the order to transform. Brown and white sprouted from her body pouring over her like a flash flood. Human features vanished as the spell manipulated her body into the shape of a white tailed deer. Large breasts became the sleek chest of a deer as her arms transformed into the legs and hooves that could speed her through the forest.

The deer that had been human took a moment to absorb her new surroundings. Marina had learned from experience that taking a moment to collect yourself and get used to your new for could save your life. Within a few minutes she was ready to continue her journey and her new legs carried her swiftly through the forest to her goal.
122.title: Take the main road to face Dreze

1221.content:
The cool air of the evening washed over the land but Marina's fur kept her insulated from the chill and her new ears allowed her to hear the symphony of the forest. Aromas flooded her nose with the fragrant smells of woodland pines and wild flowers when her nose caught the scent of something more ominous. The distinctive odor of wolf scent markings warned the primitive part of her brain that she was entering the territory of a hostile predator. Marina's civilized brain forced the fear to the back of her mind because she was on a mission was more important than avoiding every potential danger that could lurk in the woods.

It wasn't until Marina had heard the snapping of a twig from a young wolf did she realize the danger was very real. It was one to study the food chain and understand it, but quite another to become part of it. Being hunted down to feed a pack of hungry wolves was a terrifying thought and brought speed to movement through the forest. Grey, Black and white shadows raced after the frightened spell-caster with no thoughts of her status in the kingdom of Dar only thoughts of empty bellies becoming full filled their animal minds.

Marina's hoofs were keeping her ahead of the wolves but for how long? She had been running the woods for a while now and fatigue was beginning to catch up to her. It would be extremely dangerous to lose her speed before the pack lost interest and went after easier prey, but her alternatives to running weren't much better. Swift magic would be required to save her life if she chose that route but it was dangerous with the magic she had cast and could create untold side effects and she wasn't sure whether it would be better to take another animal form or take on human form to give her greater access to her magic.
1221.title: Danger! Wolves!

12211.content:
Marina decided running was her best option because she had grown very good at traveling through the forest, and this area was familiar to her, plus she heard the sound of what might be the salvation for this situation. Some of the enemy was marching down the road and wouldn’t they be surprised to see a pack of wolves led by a deer.

The soldiers heard noises from the woods but they weren’t able to draw their weapons before the animal had started passed them in a rush. Several of the men laughed at the strange behavior of the animal but it was short lived as the pack of wolves entered the road giving chase. Panic filled the men as they drew their blades to use against the fearsome animals. The wolves responded to the assault with snapping jaws leaving Marina to escape.

She debated trying to finish off the troops or if she should head off to finish her mission. Marina hated leaving the animals who attacked to be killed by the soldiers but she had a job to do that would save a lot of lives and a lot of the forest the animals roamed through. She paused for a moment debating if she had the time to save the animals. They had just been following their natural impulses.
12211.title: Keep running

122111.content:
She decided to help the wolves because the more damage they could do to the enemies the less she would have to do later, so she found cover and shifted back to human form to allow her to cast a spell. Marina focused on the wolves and cast a spell to enlarge their size.

The light leather of the soldiers was doing okay against the beasts of the woods allowing them protection against the sharp teeth but it wasn’t enough for long before the armor wasn’t enough. The wolves suddenly swelled in size until their backs were on level with the men they were fighting. New muscles allowed them to easily crush flesh and bone beneath the armor the army wore. Screams of terror and horror quickly replaced the triumphant roars that had been heard moments before.

Marina wished she could continue to watch over events but she knew she needed to be on her way. More troops would be arriving soon to assist the dying men and she didn’t want to be around when they showed up. This should allow her to be able to easily get close to the heart of the army. She took a last look at the wolves with a little sorrow knowing even with their knew size and strength they would eventually fall to the blades of the army.

Dreze had erected a powerful barrier against magic users which would slow Marina’s travel a great deal. She would need to find a way around it other than force because there were a great deal of magic users focusing their full attention on this. On the good side, the barrier meant they forces of the kingdom’s enemy would have to move very slowly and wouldn’t have the offensive power they could.
