1423.content:
Eric didn’t like it but he made the decision that made the most sense, “Let’s visit the tribe of the Raven.”

The Raven tribe could give him a lot more information and cover far greater distances than he could as a man. He didn’t like dealing with the spirits despite one residing in him all of his life. The Wolverine was a simple spirit that desired battle and blood and Eric was very willing to offer it a healthy supply but most of the spirits were tricky and manipulative beings. They had a far different understanding of things than mortals and it gave them alien views and desires. The Raven was worse than most but it was also one of the wisest.

He had done favors for the tribe in the past but it didn’t mean there would be no price to pay for going to the place. The barbarian could hear the Wolverine growl as they approached the territory of the tribe and he agreed with the sentiment. They might not be enemies of the Raven tribe but the group had started wars and death for reasons only they could see in the past.

Brightly colored flowers covered the ground as they reached the inner border of the Raven tribe. The odor coming from them was a sickly sweet scent that caused a bit of disorientation, members of the tribe had grown immune to the scent so intruders were the only ones to suffer. Arin covered her mouth with a cloth to diminish the effect but Eric didn’t bother. He had been here often enough that he could compensate for the effect.

They had been watched by the people of these lands since before entering, they watched from cover observing the visitors and assessing them. The barbarian and the bard drew to a halt at a large clearing at the center of the village. Giant trees soared high above their heads and in them, the huts of the villagers could be observed. Eric didn’t bother to call them down or try to go up after them, he had learned from past experience it was better to wait for them.

Their observers seemed to be in no rush to greet their guests so Arin pulled out a flute and started to play to amuse herself. Eric paced angrily as he waited unable to be patient, they enjoyed these games to test people and observe their reactions. Despite being heavily in his debt they still treated him as if they were doing him a favor. The barbarian was close to using his axe to take down the trees when several members of the tribe finally came down to them.

“How may we assist the great Wolverine?” the tribal elder smiled warmly as she came up in her cloak of raven feathers. Ravana was a dark haired beauty who didn’t look affected by the centuries of life she had experienced.
1423.title: Mystic

143.content:
Eric Bloodaxe had made many enemies not by leaving them alive but by building a legend around himself. It hadn’t been intentional, but he didn’t discourage it because it made many enemies hesitate that those split seconds that were essential for victory. The major problem with it was many groups looked to slay him to take his legend for them.

Five orcs stepped onto the road with a familiarity that spoke to them knowing who they were dealing with. Two of them bore the ritual scarring of the orc god of berserkers, Yagras. Another two of them were obviously whelps on their first hunt, and the final one was an alchemist with a belt full of danger around his waist.

The trick would be to take out at least one of the veterans before the rage took them. Powerful muscles launched Eric into a charge sending him forward before the orcs had prepared themselves. The charge’s momentum carried the great axe of the barbarian through the veteran’s meager defense separating his head from his shoulders and it continued its deadly path to disembowel one of the whelps.
Red filled the eyes of the remaining veteran as rage filled his body controlling his actions. He shoved aside the dying whelp to inflict a flurry of attacks against the enemy. The other whelp roared and circled the barbarian to flank him as the panicked alchemist grabbed a grenade and threw it into the air.

Eric no longer felt the nicks and cuts the orcs inflicted on him as his body fell under the sway of the rage of the wolverine. The veteran leaned into take a bite out of his opponent only to be head butted crushing his teeth and sending him staggering backwards. Eric whipped around to bury his axe in the remaining whelp and tore the orc’s sword from his hand and threw into the chest of the veteran who swung one final blow which the barbarian easily dodged, but the alchemist’s grenade burst releasing its contents.

The world began to fade even as Eric’s rage fought to keep him awake. The alchemist laughed and danced with glee at his victory, but it was short lived as a hand axe from Eric claimed his life. It would be easy to submit to the sway of the drug thought Eric as the world darkened.
143.title: Encounter an enemy on the road

1431.content:
Eric fought the urge to sleep and summoned the rage inside to burn off the drugs, and charged down the trail of where they had come from and it wasn’t long before he discovered a small tribe of the creatures and he launched himself at them. His ax cleaved the first orcs head from the body and threw it at a second orc trying to grab a weapon ending the effort. Some of them might be berserkers but they were about to learn the dangers of a real berserker.

He roared as another orc moved towards him despite having no weapon he wasn’t worried because the rage gave him an unhealthy lack of fear. The hand ax of the orc dug into his shoulder but not much as his skin was like armor and his large grabbed hold of the enemy’s head and pressed his fingers into the eyes enjoying how they squished before throwing the orc to the ground. His foot crushed the skull and silenced the screaming as he pulled the hand ax and threw it with deadly accuracy into another enemy ending the charge.

Bodies and blood covered the encampment by the time he was done, and he collapsed as his rage ended and he finally allowed himself to slumber. His mind was filled with dreams where he saw his village burning as the King laughed and he felt the rage start to build inside of him again. King Emeril had betrayed him after all of the help he had given him over the years and he was paid back by having his loved ones slain. The nightmare woke him from his dream in a sweat and he needed to decide what to do next.
Dreams were important but what did it mean? Was it telling him if he failed to complete his quest the King would destroy all that he loved? Or was it something far more sinister, could the King be planning to take the land of his tribe for himself while the tribe’s greatest warrior was away? It was very much like the mind of a “civilized” people to betray people when you have given your word especially when you considered the people savages.

His mind was one to take a course and go after it so he narrowed his choices to three. Trust the King, don’t trust him and try to save his tribe and finally he could seek out a shaman to interpret the dream.
1431.title: Stay awake

14311.content:
Eric decided he would trust King Emeril because the man had yet to wrong him and he believed in trusting his friends. A shaman may read more into the dream but a berserker lived more in the real world. Dreams were often just silly random thoughts and images, he had yet to become a purple dragon with yellow spots like he had dreamed about once. He had a mission to do and a reward to get. If the King did betray him he would soon find an ax in his head.

The trouble with the tribes was likely to have been caused by the orcs. Orcs were far closer to tribes than the civilized world and they often met on friendly terms for trade and mating but they were known to call for war every chance they got. Yargas was a god loved by many barbarians and was often used to exploit the emotions of the tribe into joining them on violent raids. If he could find the orc war leader he could end this by slaying the being.

It was a signs the gods were not with you when your war leader was slain so Eric would do his best to locate him. Finding the war leader shouldn’t be very hard because they would be calling everyone to them to get them ready for war. The problem would be in getting to the leader because he would be surrounded by bodyguards so he wouldn’t have to fight with every crazy who wanted to challenge him. Depending on how defensive the person was, Eric may have to fight many people before he could challenge the leader to combat. This, of course, depended on the war leader being honorable but if he was wasn’t it was likely the other would leave him especially the worshipers of Yargas if he acted with dishonor. That would be cold comfort to Eric’s loved ones when they were given his corpse if it came to that.

Trailing the orcs back to where they had come from seemed like the simplest solutions. If he traveled in the open he was more likely to be viewed as either a proper challenger or someone looking to join the war leader. If he traveled with more stealth he could avoid these small pockets of violent enemies. Whatever he did, Eric was sure that the spirit of the Wolverine inside of him would be well fed over the next several days.
14311.title: Trust the King

143111.content:
Traveling in the open was the way for the barbarian because he liked it when he had something he could swing his ax at. Eric was looking forward to facing down the champion of the orcs whoever it was. With the power, the spirit of the Wolverine gave him he was confident against most opponents in single combat.

It didn’t take long for him to observe movements in the rocks and woods around him but no shots were fired at him so he continued on his journey deeper into the territory of this uprising of orcs. A small barricade to the road came into view as he followed the winding path. Several barbarians stood in the mask of war and he didn’t like the tribe symbols he saw on the men, they were the Dire Bear Tribe.

Dire Bear Tribe was a violent cruel group that enjoyed destroying and dominating all around them. King Emeril had tried to wipe them from the face of earth and Eric had done his best to help the man. He had witnessed their acts of cannibalism and torture they inflicted on others. The Wolverine spirit inside of him was already growing anxious for combat and Eric was very likely to feed it the blood of these monsters but he was worried about the mission to face the one in charge of this group.

If he came in peace it was likely he would be allowed to challenge the leader but if he broke the code of peace he would be viewed as a hostile warrior and be subjected to attacks from everyone.and as good as he was he couldn’t fight an army. Eric growled as he approached the men and debated what he was going to do about it and hoped they would attack him so he could slay them and still be under the code of peace for the tribes.
143111.title: In the Open

choices: Take time to rest and heal
1431112.content:
The Dire Bear tribe was known for their tempers and desire for combat so he could perhaps provoke them into combat. It wasn’t the smartest idea since he was planning to challenge the toughest warrior ahead of him and the Dire Bear tribe was known for their fearsome warriors but he wasn’t about to let them go if he could help it. They had nearly destroyed his own tribe until he had come along and met them with power and violence they couldn’t match.

“Do your Mothers know you are outside playing at being warriors?” Eric asked them.

“Did you hear something brother, I thought I heard the squeak of a mouse?” The larger one asked his brother.

“It couldn’t have been anything larger,” the slightly smaller warrior chuckled but there was anger in the eyes of the man.

“Would you like me to help you lift your blade so you can be like the big boys?”

“I am Brun and this is my brother Tarn, you would be wise to watch your tongue around us,” the younger one took a step towards Eric trying to be menacing but the barbarian just laughed at him causing him to turn even redder.

“Don’t let him provoke you, little brother,” Tarn chided.

“You better listen to him tiny one because you are about to enter a man’s game and it isn’t a game for children.”

“You look a lot smaller than me. I have heard the stories of you and I think it is a load of garbage. You had the backing of the King to protect you. It is easy to kill when you have two hundred soldiers backing you up for every enemy you face.”

“When I said tiny, I meant the size of your brain.”

Tarn was looking to avoid the fight because he believed the stories of the monster from the tribe of Wolverine but he would back his family even when he was being stupid and Brun was certainly looking like he was ready to be. He lifted his hammer as he snarled at Eric who waited for him to take the first swing and initiate the combat. Eric almost thought he was going to back down when the swing fell hard against his shoulder dislocating it.

The spirit took him over as he leaps onto Brun as he started to pull back for another blow and smashed his skull into the nose of the man crushing it. His fist smashed into the throat of the man before he jumped back from the assault of the warrior’s brother. The swing of the two handed sword cut deep into the ground as Brun struggled to breathe. Eric's leg lashed out into the knee of Tarn crushing it drawing a grunt of pain from the man. He continued the assault by slamming his body into the much larger man separating him from his weapon. The brother could only watch as Tarn fought the furious blows of Eric the Slayer of the tribe of the Dire Bear.

Brun stumbled forward as he recovered from the blow Eric had given him as he watched his brother’s struggles against the furious pounding of fists slow and finally stop. The younger man couldn’t be sure his brother was dead but he soon would be if Brun didn’t do something. He swung his hammer at the warrior who was prepared this time for the action and rolled out of the way causing his hammer to cave in Tarn’s chest certainly ending any life that might have remained. There wasn’t much time for sorrow as Eric swung his ax into the skull of the shocked man ending him.
1431112.title: Provoke them

14311122.content:
Collecting trophies would provide evidence of his battle prowess and likely force the champion of the enemy he faced to fight him. His body cried out for him to heal especially as the power and strength of the spirit faded from his body. He grabbed the hammer and two-handed sword and strapped them to his back before leaving the place to head to the heart of the territory to the cheers of the many watching eyes.

Crowds started to form behind him with people eager to see more violence the barbarian was sure to bring with him. He could hear the whispering behind him as those who knew of him spread the word to those who didn’t. It wouldn’t be long before money started to exchange hands as bets were placed on what he would do and one whether he would leave here alive.

The path widened into a large valley where Eric could see many campfires and estimated there to be at least ten thousand people in the valley. Whoever had brought this gathering together was planning more than simple raiding. Whoever the champion was was certain to be a fearsome opponent that he might not be able to take on his own.

As he was reaching the center of the camp he saw a man wearing the symbols of the chieftain of the Dire Bear tribe rise and start towards him when he saw the weapons Eric carried on his back but several others stepped forward to halt him. A lizardman of a species unknown to the barbarian stepped out of a large tent followed by a drow and an Orc shaman.

They appeared to be getting ready to talk so, the warrior debated if he should interrupt them or let them speak first. The group eyed him with caution and a hint of fear.
14311122.title: Take trophies

143111222.content:
Eric decided it was best to let them talk because it would give him time to heal. His stare watched them closely and he could see they were returning the attention to him. The crowds were starting to turn away from the group with their attention focused on the newcomer. There was blood in the air and they were excited to see more if possible. The barbarian had already slain two powerful warriors and the story of the battle was already spreading to those who hadn’t seen it. The warriors were starting to focus on what the famed fighter would do next over what the group of leaders had to say.

The lizardman stepped forward, “Too long have you bowed to the civilized world, you have given them your best while they give you scrapes. How often have your warriors saved them from the dangers that threatened to destroy their world? The blood of your sons and daughters has secured their futures. They have grown strong while feeding off of your future, your children.”

“So your offer is more war?” Eric shouted over the lizardman drawing laughter from the crowd. “Perhaps you don’t remember the days of constant war between the tribes when there was fear every day of raids and blood feuds. There was no time for planting and hunting, you talk of being given scrapes when we used to have to kill for less than a morsel of food. We have lost many in battle but that has always occurred, under King Emeril, our numbers have grown look around you and see that we are stronger than ever, you have never even heard of a gathering of this size.”

Anger filled the voice of the lizardman, “These words come from the lapdog of the King. How much of your fellow barbarian’s blood stain your attack?”

“Hundreds if not thousands,” Eric responded without hesitation. “I would slay many more if it meant the ending of the murder of children, and cannibalism that I have seen from some present here today.”

The chieftain of the Cave Bear Tribe took a step towards Eric who was eager to do battle with the man but he was held up by the orc shaman. They didn’t want this to come down to a simple duel, they had been working and planning on this for years and they had little interest in gambling it on something that was less than a sure thing. The group eyed the intruder unsure of how to get rid of him without drawing the ire of the crowd. Laric the drow could already see the crowd starting to turn on them.

The drow was sorely tempted to sneak around the back of the man and stick a poison him but it would ruin everything they were working for. They were already distrusted for being mostly outsiders. They needed to come up with a plan.
143111222.title: Let them talk

1431112221.content:
Delaying the crowd wouldn’t work, they were ready for blood but he strongly suspected the chieftain wouldn’t fair well. The drow had heard of the extermination campaign carried out by Eric against the Cave Bear Clan, it had earned him a legendary status even outside of the tribes of the north. Even in the wounded state, he was in Laric suspected Eric would find more than enough strength to slaughter his opponent and the bloodthirsty barbarian would enjoy every minute of it. The man appeared to be trying to decide which would hurt the chieftain more slaying him with one of the man’s former comrade's weapons or using the infamous blood ax against him so he could join the rest of his tribe in death.

Time was running out fast after so much excitement the crowds wanted to see some action. If they didn’t do something quickly they would lose their army by looking weak. It appeared his companions were lost in what to do. The Chieftain was muttering angrily without looking up as the events transpired around him, the fool was a hot head but he needed the tribe to act as champions as front insiders, barbarians knew a drow was not to be trusted. and the shaman looked scared, deep down the drow knew the lizard was a coward but he needed the man’s magic and persuasion. Many of the tribes respected shamans very deeply and without one to endorse this plan it would be doomed. It was up to Laric to do something to save the day as it seemed to happen all too often but it was better than dealing with the other drow. A male drow was never given the chances he had gotten in this outside world.

“The champion Eric the Blood Ax has already done honorable in combat but we can’t just let him destroy the hope for the tribes of the north,” Laric spun his words to the bloodthirsty crowds. “Why spill more of our blood when we have mutual enemies we can fight. I know of a drow outpost not far from here where the ax of the legendary warrior Stroman is held as a trophy. Whoever can return it here shall decide the course we take, is it agreed?”

It was a big risk revealing that but he needed the time and it would give some good payback to those who had exiled him. Many here would make this attempt and if they didn’t want to side with the drow there could be accidents on the way back. This would give the drow the time he needed to strike Eric when there weren’t so many witnesses. The crowd was already talking loudly about who would go and who would stay.

“I gladly accept the chance to bring back the ax of Stroman back to the tribes,” Eric yelled as his eyes turned towards the Chieftain, and Laric realized he wasn’t the only one who planned to kill.
1431112221.title: Delay for time

1431112222.content:
Chieftain Barc shoved aside the shaman and the drow, no longer able to contain his rage, “I accept your challenge little man or are you ready to fight a real warrior you overrated nothing.”

The words were hollow to the crowds and even in his own heart, he knew this man had earned the respect through combat countless times before. His tribe had nearly been sent to extinction by the man, he knew the deadly prowess of the barbarian better than anyone present and he was scared but this was the best chance to avenge his tribe and there was more.

He had met the Blood Ax once before many years ago when his brother and Father had died. Barc could practically see the spirit of the Wolverine take shape in the man. They moved as one slaughtering all in front of them wallowing in the blood. He was cut and wounded, his blade broke and he was outnumbered but Eric fought on not looking like an underdog in the fight.

To his eternal shame, he had hidden to avoid the fury of the monster coated in his loved one's blood. Once his tribe had been the most feared of the tribes but they were brought low by one man. Only by killing the man would he ever be able to speak to his ancestors again without shame. Today he would make the name for the Clan of the Cave Bear as a group to be feared.

“This isn’t wise,” Laric hissed at him. “We can’t afford to lose anyone else if we are to succeed.”

“I won’t lose!” Barc snapped. “Your keen eyes should be able to see how drained from the last battle he is.”

“True, but though I am not an expert in the ways of spirits I know the spirit of the Wolverine feasts upon rage and from the look in his eyes you are giving it a banquet.”

“It is true,” Sasska the shaman pleaded. “He has already called upon the connection a great deal this day yet I can feel the spirit returning as the hate rises in him. The spirit will be with him this battle, we need another plan.”

“I hate cowards,” himself most of all he thought as he stepped into the circle of death that was forming. “Even if a spirit is with him he is half dead already from his injuries.”

Any further words they had against the fight were drowned out by the crowd. The feud between the Tribe of the Cave Bear and the Blood Ax was legendary and all were eager to see how it would end. Would the legend finish the genocidal journey he had started or would the Chieftain end the murder spree to win back the honor of his tribe?

Barc had tried to call upon the spirit of his tribe before but all he had ever gotten was some angry distant rumbling. Perhaps the shamans of his tribe could explain but they had been slain long ago. He would be doing this battle alone and he intended to end it quickly.

The swing of the Chieftain sent Eric tumbling across the ground even with the deflection of the mace. His muscles cried out for rest and time to heal but he refused with being so close to his longtime dream. Eric swung at the man’s legs causing him to jump back from the attack but he was already propelling himself forward for another attack against the smaller figure.

Hope started to swell in the Chieftain as the battle continued, his opponent was suffering greatly from his injuries. He was struggling even to defend himself much less return the attack but he didn’t dare slow down his onslaught. It wouldn’t be long before the man took an injury that would doom him but it started to worry him that the man wasn’t getting any slower.

Pain and weakness faded from his body as Eric faded into his element, battle. He was never as at home as when he was fighting for his life or someone else’s life. The Wolverine could be seen by him watching the battle, waiting for him to earn its assistance. With a smile, he accepted the challenge dropping his ax to the shock of the crowd and more importantly his opponent.

His hand shot for the face managing to gouge out one eye as the man turned from the attack. Barc drew back in fear as he could see the ancient animal spirit take hold of the man as it had the day so long ago. Eric let loose a beastly sound that was a mix of animal and man drawing pleased cries from the crowd especially as he kicked aside his weapon but Barc wasn’t about to drop his own and lose his advantage.

There was no more defense in the charge of Eric and he was met by the mace breaking ribs but his hands had already grabbed hold of the larger man and pulled him to his goal. The barbarian’s teeth tore through the flesh of the throat.

Barc was a dead man and all present knew it. Cheers to victory filled the air as the drow and lizardman slunk away to avoid the wrath of the crowd now that they had a new champion. The Chieftan was left alone on the ground to die and join his ancestors as a failure.

“A champion deserves a prize,” a shaman stepped forward from the crowd. “We are yours to command. The spirits are honored by your victory, never have I seen one so connected to the world of the spirits. I offer you more than the service of my tribe I offer you a gift.
1431112222.title: Offer a challenge

14311122221.content:
Raven’s Eye motioned a crooked finger towards the crowd and the group part as a beautiful woman was poked and prodded until she was in front of Eric. Leather straps bound the woman’s hands and feet making a jerky movement. Underneath a heavy layer of dirt, a beautiful woman could be seen, her emerald eyes gave him a challenge to him, daring him to act against her will despite her bound situation.

“She has a lot of fight in her, she will produce great warriors for you,” the shaman smiled. “Her tongue is as sharp as any blade.”

“I thank you for such a fine gift,” Eric didn’t want a slave but refusing the woman might start a battle, not something he was interested in after the fight he just had, his body cried at him to find somewhere to curl up for three days to heal. “I would buy a horse to carry my prize home with me.”

He jingled his coin purse bringing an immediate rush to bring forth the finest animals, Eric enjoyed complimenting many of the fine specimens he found, giving a little smirk when he saw markings of the army of the kingdom of Dar’s army on more than a few of the animals. After a suitable debate he selected two of the larger animals that could be converted to farm work later if he wanted, they would be more than strong enough to carry his large frame and the tiny burden he had for the time being.

“I wish all of you the best but I am heading home for I need no help breaking in such a fine new animal,” the crowd laughed and more than a few offered him lewd suggestions that could make a sailor blush.

Exhaustion started to take hold of him by the time he had put a short distance from the encampment, it was tempting to push on but he had grown wise enough to stop and set up camp before he started making bad decisions. He released the girl from the straps binding her to the animal, she lashed out at him with a swing at one of his wounds but he pushed her to the ground.

“I can strap you to a tree, bound and gagged if that tickles your fancy or you can sleep on a soft bedroll, the choice is yours,” he cautious moved to remove the gag to hear her answer.

“I haven’t lost so much pride as to share a bed with a savage!” she gave him a deadly glare.

“There is no intention to share with such a beast as yourself on my part,” he tossed her a separate bedroll. “I am hungry and tired so I will eat and sleep.”

“Release me!” she commanded.

“Fine, if that is what you want but it would be most unwise to flee this camp.”

A sharp knife made short work of the straps holding her captive, she rushed forward as soon as she was free to jump on the closest horse but stopped when she saw Eric making no move to stop her, he continued the task of making camp, starting a fire, and making a meal for the evening.

“What do you mean it is unwise for me to escape?” she asked cautiously.

“We are not far from the great encampment you were just at,” Eric didn’t even bother looking up from his work. “You have no food, no weapon, no idea where you are, and barbarians all around who would be happy to make a slave of one as pretty as you so go if you want many have made such stupid decisions before and many more will make such stupid decisions in the future.”

“What do you propose I do?”

“Travel with me to my tribe and I will give you food, money, and horse so you can get where you want to be in return I get the joy of returning freedom to someone.”

“Thank you for helping me, you see I am really . . .”
14311122221.title: A woman

143111222212.content:
“Prince Henry,” she announced.

“How nice for you,” Eric replied before rolling over to go to sleep.

“What do you have have to say to that!?! I have just announced myself to be the King’s son. Surely you must have some to say about it!”

“Either you are crazy or telling the truth. Either way, I will deal with it better in the morning.”

This didn’t satisfy the buxom blonde who stalked around the barbarian and stared at him. She practically glowed red with rage as the eye of the man slid back open.

“I need your help,” she commanded. The attitude was enough to make Eric suspect she was telling the truth. It took practice to form such an entitled attitude.

“You were offered freedom from me. What more could you want?” irritation was sneaking into his voice.

“We must go immediately to overthrown my father. He is responsible for my current condition and must pay for it.”

“Nothing must be done immediately. People and more importantly horses need sleep. As to your father I have no reason to fight him. He pays me for my work. If you are looking for a hero I suggest you go looking for a knight or a paladin. My heroics require payment and I can clearly see you have no coins on your body.”

Her body blushed to a beautiful red as she tried to cover her body. Henry pouted at the barbarian’s amused chuckling. A thought suddenly occurred and she started to sway as she approached Eric displaying all of her wonderful curves.

“There is one thing I can pay you with,” she leaned forward giving him a view of perhaps the finest breasts he had seen and he had seen many.

“Are you certain you wish to part with such a gem?” Eric was on his feet in an instant with his battle harden muscles pressed against her soft flesh. She squealed in surprise as she felt his hardened penis against her. “You were a real ladies man. Do those skills translate?”

The last words had been whispered softly into her ear with primal hunger. Suddenly she was released for a hard fall to the ground. Blinking in surprise she heard the laughter of the warrior telling her she had been messed with again.

“I don’t suggest you offer me such a tantalizing prize,” He dropped back under his blanket. “Next time I might just take it.”

Eric thanked the gods when he heard her shift under her blanket allowing him to sleep. The fire had faded to nothing but embers when he heard the quiet approach of someone. Dawn was just hinting that it wanted to peek over the horizon but his keen eyes recognized the form of the naked woman. She crawled under the blanket with him. Her engorged nipples just touch his bare torso.
143111222212.title: A man

14312.content:
Eric had few people in life that he trusted and the King wasn’t one of them. He had seen the man betray those who were loyal to him in the past to help his kingdom and there were many reasons to throw aside a barbarian and his tribe. As times became more peaceful civilization liked to push outwards into the wilderness. His land was not fertile ground so there had to be another reason, metal or something else that could be pulled from the earth would give a justification to the slaughtering of a people. Fear grew in him and he found his path turning towards his village.

He didn’t have any certainty that he was right but it wouldn’t hurt to check, King Emeril had been very vague about the threat to the north, had it all been a ruse to lead him away from his people. Without men to lead he would be just a lone warrior fighting a lost cause. Most of the warriors would be away from the village this time of year trying to slay mammoths for the approaching winter and they wouldn’t expect an ambush on the way back.

His body wanted to walk but it kept going faster as the possibility of an attack festered and grew in his mind. Why hadn’t the King slain or caught him in the city if treason was happening, he tried to calm his mind but it did little good. An incident in the city would have spread the news far and wide and there were many who were sympathetic to the barbarians for the assistance they had given Dar over the years, no it would be better for him to die against one of the dangers lurking out in the tribal territories or at least get back too late to find evidence of what had really happened.

The smell of fire tickled his nose and he knew that he was getting close to people but he couldn’t be sure who they were, he slowed his pace so he could listen and rest for any battle that was to come. The room fell silent as everyone waited and wondered what would happen next.

“I apologize,” Karas said as he dropped some coins on the table. “The lady looked like she might spill for . . . some reason, so I came to help and bumped into you. I hope buying your table a round of drink will make up for the . . . accident.”

Anger at being hit rose in the man but his thoughts changed as the sound of the metal-clad hands of Karas drummed away at his sword grip, waiting for the man’s decision. The man grumbled something and went back to drinking. The lady would be safe for the rest of the night as none in the room had a great desire to take on the heavily armed man. Karas for his part was glad he still had a bed in his future as well as a warm meal. The stew was made from some of the local wild game, and the brew was a nice and heavy imported northern brew. He was careful to keep an eye on the man he had hurt in case the alcohol he was taking in like a fish gave him some liquid courage.
1513.title: Why seek trouble when you can avoid it?

15132.content:
Karas drank his beer in just two swallows happy to have something other than water in his belly. Being on a mission meant he could only allow himself one a day. Any more and he risked losing his edge but a single beer could help to mellow and relax him in battle. This town didn’t look like it was under the iron fist of a knight but the villain could just come by to collect his “taxes.”

The humiliated man was talking quietly with his comrades but as long as that was all he did they would be safe. Farmers and locals had little use for soldiers or adventurers and gripping about them helped prevent them from doing something stupid. Adventurers might slay a beast or kill an orc raiding party but they usually the opposite of helpful. For every story of help, there was usually five where they seduced a daughter, made unreasonable demands or took a precious child away from the farm to work for them with dreams of high adventure. The fighter had been born upon a farm and been lured away for a life of cold beds, painful wounds, and an empty coin purse most of the time.

There was no way he was going to pass up a hot meal to satisfy the anger of some drunken assholes. Even a plain stew was better than what he had mastered in cooking on the road. Years had not improved the toxic concoctions he produced leaving him with dry rations. It was enough to make an adventurer miss the farm.

“You are in my seat,” a giant of a man slapped a hand on Karas’s shoulder and yanked him around.

The grinned at the table across the room. It didn’t a wizard to figure out this guard had been summoned to deal with him by the asshole. The problem for them was the size, authority and armor didn’t always make a dangerous warrior.

Karas stared at him in the eye as his foot smashed the knee out from the giant. He grunted he collapsed under his weight.

“Feel free to have it,” twisting around his opponent slamming the giant’s head into the thick wooden chair.

“You are messing with the guard!” the asshole roared. “We are placing you under arrest.”

“If you fight me, you are going to make it worth my time,” Karas’s eyes flashed. “Are you willing to pay the price? Because your friend doesn't seem to be doing so well after paying up."
15132.title: The man wants to cause trouble

choices: Strike hard and fast like the boa to crush your foes
Observe and await the proper time like the crocodile
Ambush like the cobra taking down a foe with speed
152.content:
Sitha was fascinated by the world of the civilized races because it was so different from the simple life the lizardmen led. He wondered which was the better choice or if they were simply different. The rabbit and the deer were different from each other and neither was better, or worse than the other they were only different with their own places in the world. The King of the humans had called for his help and he answered because Sitha was curious why a human who commanded so many would seek the help of one of the lizard people.

The castle was the most impressive building of stone Sitha had seen outside of the ominous stone structures in the heart of the swamp which the lizardmen were forbidden to explore, because of the dark bloody history behind it. It didn’t take long for armored men to guide him to the King which wasn’t surprising because a seven foot tall lizardman stood out in a crowd. Light orbs lit the castle in a gentle glow allowing the painting and tapestries to be properly admired.

King Emeril sat on his throne and waved all of the guards from the room leaving him alone with the large lizard man. The elderly man looked nervous, but Sitha was pleased at the display of trust the King showed by being alone with him.

“I seek your aid in a very delicate matter,” the King said. “In return I will offer you the Eye of the Lizard Kings.”

The Eye of the Lizard Kings was an extremely important relic from the days of the lizard empire many millennium ago. There was very little any of the lizardmen wouldn’t do to get it back for the tribes of lizardmen everywhere, because it could act as a source of unity for the diverse tribes of lizardmen and prevent the common tribal warfare that existed now. Sitha was more curious than ever as to what great task would be required of him to earn the Eye.

“My son Stephan is gathering a large group of mercanaries to use against me,” King Emeril explained. “I need you to kill him before he throws this kingdom into a civil war with many pointless deaths.”

“For the Eye I am willing to do this,” Sitha agreed.

“Thank you for taking on this job. You can find him at the outpost called Travia’s Haven where he and the mercenaries are hidden in one of the valleys nearby. If you can make sure no one observes your action against the prince.”

There was sorrow in the King’s eyes but Sitha only cared about earning the reward promised to him. He would have a choice to make. Should he strike the Prince at the outpost, take time to observe his target or set-up an ambush.
152.title: Sitha Blackscale Fearsome Lizard Man

1521.content:
Sitha enjoyed combat and he had little doubt he could take out this small band of warriors if he struck hard and fast. The sight of the outpost told him he had made the right choice because it was in poor condition as he approached. Workers tried to patch holes in the walls as others removed rotten wood from the walls. It wouldn’t take long for them to repair the defenses, a few days at most, but until then they would be easy pickings. He would wait for darkness before he started his strikes against them because their sight was poor, but his was excellent under the shroud of night. If things went well he might not have to take many strikes against the location. The Prince was not likely to be one of the men on guard duty, so he would have to be patient to get his target without getting killed.

Few torches were lit that night and even fewer men were on guard. The men stank of sweat and hard work indicating the ones he saw working earlier were these same men which bode well for an attack as their strength, and senses would be diminished by a hard day of labor. The jaws of Sitha latched on the throat of a man on guard duty who had made the mistake of falling asleep cutting his life short. The lizardman left him at his post so he would have an exit if he needed it.

If the number of guards was around the number of workers there would be at least twenty men, a daunting number even if they were tired but Sitha was determined to make it work if he could. This outpost was designed for many more men and it was likely reinforcements could be on their way. He moved quickly to strike a second guard along the wall who yelled in startled surprise when he saw Sitha but it changed into a scream as the muscles of the powerful lizardman threw him over the side outside of the outpost to his death or injury as Sitha leaped into the compound.

The lizard moved to hide in shadows and waited for the cries to draw attention of the camp. He could try and find the location or try and slaughter the unarmed and unarmored men in the barracks. Both had there advantages and disadvantages and he didn’t have much time to make the choice.
1521.title: Strike hard and fast like the boa to crush your...

15211.content:
Sitha decided to go after the Prince in the chaos caused by the death of the guard, because that was his job. He didn’t mind killing off humans, they certainly had no problems killing his people, but it was wasted energy to kill the others. Death should serve a purpose and only the death of the Prince would get him paid so he started moving towards the building where two guards had not moved an inch at the alarms sounding. They must be guarding something important and royalty often thought they were the most important thing around.

He wished he had skill with a bow but though he had tried, the mastery of it eluded him, but he was good with a javelin. The light spear flew the air with deadly accuracy into the unarmored throat of one of the guards holding in upright as the second guard rushed to end the threat of the attacker. Sitha brought his long sword down with incredible force causing the guard to drop back, but the lizardman pressed his attack using his superior strength to his advantage. Humans often had better endurance than lizardmen and Sitha might have to call upon his endurance tonight if things went poorly, so he wanted to finish this quickly if he could. The man grunted in pain as the lizardman dug his blade into his shoulder, but he continued fighting back with a quick slash at the belly of his opponent. Leather armor tore from the sharp blade but the hard scales underneath didn’t give way, the man saw he was doomed and tried to call for help as a last desperate act to try and save his master.

“To arms! To ar . . .” the blade of the lizardman ended the call for help.

The humans would turn their attention to him soon if they heard the cries for help, so fleeing would be the safest option but Sitha was so close to victory.
15211.title: Look for the Prince

152111.content:
Sitha decided to gamble on the Prince being inside the building and rush an attack. Most of the people in the compound would think they were under attack, not realizing it was an assassin they were dealing with. The wood was old and rotten with time so with a powerful slamming of his shoulder against the door splintered and opened to reveal a man dressing in his armor looking up in surprise. He wore the herald markings of the Prince and he reacted quickly to the intruder lifting his blade to a defensive position.

The Prince of a more civilized kingdom might not be trained in the proper use of arms, but the Kingdom of Dar needed every fighting hand it could get. A quick slash of the blade drew blood from the lizardman but the warrior prince was careful to not over extend himself. This was going to be a dangerous battle even for the seasoned warrior Sitha. The human was leaving itself open but the creature would not take the bait because it could sense the trap instead the assassin decided to offer a trap of it’s own. Sitha brought the long sword down with both hands driving for the shoulder but leaving his belly open and the man took the bait using his free hand to place a dagger in the belly of the lizardman, but as Sitha winced with pain he made his move and the human realized his error too late.

The powerful reptile jaws tore deeply into the soft vulnerable flesh of the human throat. Most humans were used to fighting human and other creatures that were unable to make powerful bite attacks. It was a mistake to leave yourself open to the bite of a lizardman the Prince thought as his blood streamed from his throat even as he tried to stop it. Sitha had stepped back from his opponent to let him die so he could look to his own wound. He bound it as best he could before someone came to check on the Prince but it didn’t look good. He felt sluggish as he struck the head from the shoulders of the corpse in from of him and made his way out of the camp.

He wished he had observed the area better for likely hideouts where he could hold up and heal after killing the Prince but he had not. The death of Royalty never came without consequences and he was likely to have the rest of the camp chase him and who new how many others. He had some hard choices ahead of him.
152111.title: Press his luck

1521111.content:
He could try and tough out the injury but that was stupid when you are being chased. It would be better to find a location he could hide at while they chased him. He doubted they would find him because they had struck him as military trained soldiers and not tracks but they could very easily find someone to track for them. Finding a good tracker would take time and the longer they took the less people they would have to use against Sitha, as their leader was dead there would soon be many deserters.

The wound had been bound so there would be no blood trail as he moved to through the forest to his target. He did his best not leave a good trail but he cared more for speed so he could make it to the abandoned village before dawn. It had not been abandoned willingly as the scars of battle still showed after many years. He climbed up the back of a two story building hoping his claw marks looked like the wear of time or battle marks and crawled into an open window.

Floorboard creaked with his foot steps but they gave no signs of giving way to his weight. The stairway had been barricaded against intruders, and he casually wondered if the people had managed to survive the attack of orcs that had brought this village it’s end. Sleep was calling to him but he wanted to see what, if anything, the other rooms held.

A second room gave evidence that the people who had once been here didn’t survive as numerous skeletons and blood stains decorated the room. The windows had been destroyed indicating it had been a likely entry point for the orcs. The final room bore some scorch marks and the stench of magic from the combat long ago. Despite not liking magic he decided this was the best room to stay in as the other rooms had open window entrances.

He curled up in a corner hidden behind a desk and allowed slumber to take him. Thankfully lizard men healed much more quickly than humans, and he would be much better in the morning but he would want to stick around for several days to fully heal. The hunting was good around here but he would want to limit that to avoid creating an easy trail for people to follow. Sitha preferred to cook meat but that would be too risky with people likely following him. It was a waiting game to see if they found him, or if he had the time to heal.
1521111.title: Find Shelter

15211111.content:
Sitha wasn’t sure how much sleep he had gotten when noises woke him from his sleeping, but he quickly brought his sword to the ready but he quickly realized there was no one living moving around the building as he saw a spectral figure run past the door. The warrior pulled out some jerky and tore a large chunk off and started to eat as he decided what to do next.

He gently touched his wound to get a sense of the healing that had occurred and found it to still be very tender. No heavy efforts should be done until it healed more but he wasn’t comfortable sticking around here with the dead on the move. Ghosts of lizard men were loved and respected for the knowledge, and wisdom they could tell you and were never known to harm the living as they were dead and belonged to that world, but as in many things, humans were different.

Many tales of the harm ghosts could cause had been told to him in his travels, and it seemed to him that humans were unwilling to give up on the lives they had lived. They were often determined to have revenge even after they had died instead of moving on with the cycle of life as determined by the fates. Sitha could see that it brought many of them great accomplishments that were thought impossible, but it rarely brought them happiness. They never seemed able to settle down and enjoy life, there was always some new goal to achieve.

It was best not to linger with all of these restless ghosts around searching to undo what had been done to them. He cautiously moved towards the place he had come in and hoped the spirits were just replaying the last tragic moments of their lives. Perhaps with his reward, he could see about the shamans putting these people to rest. They didn’t deserve to spend the rest of time stuck here.

As he moved to go down the rope a sight at the end of the hall caught his eye. A female ghost with long dark hair was staring at him. She started walking towards him with a purpose and he debated running from this intelligent ghost or trying to talk to it. Either choice had danger involved with it, but he was going to lose the chance to run if he didn’t go soon.
15211111.title: The dead aren't at rest

152111113.content:
Sitha froze with indecision as he debated what to do next, but the ghost did not. It lunged at him and he felt an icy chill as it entered his body. He looked around but he couldn’t see where it had gone, he hoped it had left him but he wasn’t going to stick around to find out what it was up to. The warrior had great experience in fighting the living but none in fighting the dead, and he didn’t want to gain any when he was at such a disadvantage.

Pain from his wounds finally called on him to stop and fall into another deep slumber on the soft, moist earth. He knew he should have stopped sooner but he wanted to be as far away from there as possible. The sleep was dreamless, and good for his recovery as the pain from his wound no longer bothered him.

Taking a look at the wound he found it had healed and was no longer tender to the touch, but it had no scales over. The flesh looked like the skin of a human, and his size had diminished, he was certain the ghost had done something to him. Tightening his belt he continued on his journey, but he wasn’t looking forward to what likely had to be done. Magic was involved and magic was the likely solution to his problems.

His first thought was to go to the shamans of his tribe but they were far from here and he strongly suspected the changes the ghost was doing to him were not finished with him. The sooner Sitha the easier the solution was likely to be, but the magic of the humans and other creatures were strange to him. One of the holy people might have the answer because they were good with curses and the undead but they had many rules and strange customs. They often mocked him for his “primitive” ways that were far more in touch with nature and the land. The humans wanted to call on divine beings that were distant and alien to life on earth. They didn’t experience the pains and sufferings of mortals, so how could they be trusted with the care of mortals. The last option was the one that frightened him the most.

Wizards and their ilk were terrifying to him because they dealt in forces that were far beyond their control and understanding yet these beings acted like they were the masters of it. Many would likely have the intelligence and knowledge to help him but there was a danger that they would treat him as an experiment for their own selfish power and gain. There was also the chance they would fail him as they over reached their skills and abilities, few wizards ever doubted their chances of success and their failures often had terrible consequences.

It was a scary choice to have to make when all he really wanted to do was go and collect his reward for his victory, but this was a problem he needed to take care of first.
152111113.title: The ghost possesses him

1521111131.content:
The armor she was wearing was becoming heavy and exhausting so she lifted it from her body and dropped it to the ground. She had traveled for days without rest and never noticed the weight of the armor before. Human bodies were so weak and what was with these fleshy protrusions on this body, they would create difficulty in combat. Sitha poked one of the mounds on her chest and was surprised by the jolt of pleasure she felt but was no closer to figuring out the purpose.

She had decided to head for the shaman of her tribe but the distance was starting to wear on her new form. Even the loss of the armor and dropping her large weapon hadn’t stopped the difficulties for the warrior. Her new chest swayed and jiggled with every step she took causing her to finally take her blanket out a strip of cloth out to wrap her chest up as best she could with the still swelling mounds on her chest.

The changes had continued and she was certain that it wouldn’t be long before she was fully human and she wondered how she would explain that to the shaman because they weren’t used to humans asking for assistance. Sitha wished she had studied humans more but she had cared very little about them. What was the function of the female in human society and how were they supposed to behave? She needed to act human in case she was discovered by others but at least she would be hard to discover by the remaining warriors of the prince she had slain.

There appeared to be a small village ahead of her that she debated about stopping at. She wasn’t sure she was comfortable pretending to be human yet but she was hot and leaking water profusely. Perhaps there was someone in town who could help her situation.
1521111131.title: Visit Shaman

choices: "Your quest is important you must continue it."
15211111313.content:
Thundering hooves and clattering metal filled the ears of Sitha as she listened to the approaching riders and to her dismay they bore the markings of the Prince he had slain. There was a group of seven armor knights moved quickly to surround her. They circled her in a tight formation attempting to scare her, for amusement or to intimidate her she wasn’t sure but she watched them closely trying to determine the leader. It was frustrating not having her former strength or weapons but as long as she stayed focused on actions she wouldn’t allow herself to be scared.

“Why are you blocking me?” Sitha asked trying to hide the anger and fear from her voice.

“We are searching for a killer young lady,” one of the men said in a menacing tone. “Have you seen a lizard man in the area?”

“Not recently. I wish to be on my way.”

“It would be safer if you would travel with us, young lady. Your attire suggests you have already had some trouble, we will see you safely to the next town. We are on a mission of the utmost importance or we would seek the ones who have harmed one as lovely as yourself.”

Sitha could feel the heat of a blush on her face but didn’t understand what was happening to her. She didn’t want to travel with the knights in case they didn’t have the noble intentions they claimed, and the longer she traveled with them the more likely they would discover she wasn’t what she appeared to be. Things would be easier if she could see their faces so she could try and read them but all she saw was cold steel masks.

“I had an accident but I am fine now. I will get some new clothes in town and it isn’t much farther.”
15211111313.title: Encounter with a hunting party

152111113131.content:
“. . . you to the village,” the man grabbed hold of her arm and lifted her onto his horse. “Don’t worry to ride is short and I think you will enjoy it. My name is Sir Jack.”

Sitha started to protest but the knight had already coaxed his horse into motion. She had been hoping to arrive in town unnoticed but she didn’t think the knight was going to listen to any further arguments. The warrior often wondered how the metal-clad warriors became of how certain of their every decision they were. Was it the heavy armor they wore or some sort of training they received? This knight hadn’t even asked for her name as if all that mattered was his own.

The garments she was wearing needed to be traded in for something better because her chest was bouncing around like a couple of boulders tumbling down a hill. The knight grabbed hold of her chest crushing her body against his. It stopped much of the jiggling but it upset her because it seemed like he wasn’t doing it for her safety. Several of the other knights were laughing at her plight which caused her face to burn.

Anger started to swell in her that this person was having fun at her expense and she didn’t like it. A voice whispered inside her mind that she should teach the knight some manners. As the dirt road changed into a cobblestone road and the village came into view she decided she had had enough and leaped off the horse shoving the man’s arm aside.

Sitha spun towards Sir Jack and grabbed his foot and jerk it up and over the side of the horse. The force of gravity did the rest and sent the man tumbling to the ground in a loud clattering sound that started to be drowned out by the laughter of his companions. Sir Jack didn’t find it as funny as the rest of the knights as he lifted his mud covered faceplate to reveal a nearly purple with anger face but Sitha had no sympathy for him.

“A knight should act like a knight if I had to guess from your behavior I would say you are an ass,” she said with a cold stare. “It is rare to see an ass ride a horse but the amusement has worn thin I think I have had enough of your company. I suggest we avoid each other for the rest of our time in the village.”

The words didn’t seem to be her own and that worried the former lizard-man. Was he losing his mind as well as his body? The thought scared her but she would leave it for later because she had a dangerously angry knight in front of her to deal with. Most of the companions were still laughing at their friend and had failed to notice the deep anger so she doubted she could depend on their assistance in the matter.
152111113131.title: "We insist on taking"

1521111131311.content:
Emily Hargraves had died many years ago but she had a strong will and refused to give up on life until her mission was complete. Sitha was unsure of how to handle the man and was confused by human interactions but she wasn’t so she took charge. This man was a predator of women and needed to be dealt with as such.

“Back off before I hurt you,” Emily ordered.

“You don’t tell a knight of the realm what to do,” Sir Jack moved close with his hand on his blade. “We keep order for the lands.”

“You don’t do a very good job of it when you threaten the citizens!” Emily countered. “I suggest you not come any closer to me.”

“Or you will do what?” the man took a deliberate step forward with each word.

A gust of wind struck the man square in his chest as commanded by the beautiful woman and sent him flying several feet back to the ground. Emily glanced carefully around at the man’s companions to see what they were up to. They had pulled their horses back a short distance and looked like they were debating what to do next. It was one thing to mess with a defenseless peasant girl but quite another to harass a female spell caster who may have a great deal of power. As they were thinking up their next actions she was placing magical defenses on herself.

“I suggest you find your sport somewhere else before you get burned,” she directed her threat against Sir Jack to help divide him from the group. Emily suspected that the others were not always innocent bystanders but she didn’t want to encourage the others to assist their friend.

“I won’t let you beat me,” Sir Jack got up from the ground as he pulled his blade out and started towards Emily.

She shook her head at the stupidity but she let loose great cone of flames from her hands shot forth coating the man in fire melting flesh and bone dropping an ash filled, a charred black suit of armor to the ground. She whipped around to face the horrified other members of the group but she was thankful that none of them had pulled their weapons yet.

“I suggest you see to your friend and you go looking for whatever you are looking somewhere else because I don’t want any more dealings with you and I am certain you want no more dealings with me,” Emily stated cautiously.
1521111131311.title: The ghost takes charge

15211111313112.content:
“Let’s go separate directions,” the Knight said. “I think we have had enough bloodshed for the day.”

Emily gave a slight nod but she kept her fire magic up until they were out of sight. She wiped the sweat from her brow, glad that the strain from keeping the magic up was over. The young woman moved quickly into the safety of the village in case the group decided to double back. She wasn’t sure if they really felt she was justified in killing the man or if they just didn’t want to fight her, either way, she was happy to have them gone.

Rustling Leaves was a small village with a large population of elves and humans living in harmony. It was known for the healing herbs and remedies and the people were friendly even to strangers. Emily went to the Golden Goose Inn, a luxury inn, and secured a room. It would be nice to have a warm bath and a soft bed again but the real reason she had splurged on the room with the lizardman’s money was the mirror. A giant lizardman looked at her angrily from the mirror at her and she could understand it, considering what she had done to his body, but she needed to finish her mission.

“I am sorry for what I have done to you but I have a mission I must complete,” Emily explained. “I shall return this body to you once my quest is done.”

“You have been dead for many years human,” Sitha growled. “Your mission is no longer of importance. This world is for the living not the dead. I suggest you return to the grave.”

“The danger still remains, it was why I was killed. I promise to give you a reward if you work with me but if you want to fight me I will fight back and both of us will be likely to lose.”
15211111313112.title: He was a jerk

152111113131121.content:
Sitha wished that he understood more about the supernatural and ghosts but they were not something talked about in the lizardfolk community. He had never heard of one of his people returning from the dead but if one had come back then surely it would be for a good reason. She seemed genuinely worried about something and he decided to give her the benefit of the doubt.

“I shall try to work with you,” Sitha told Emily.

Relief formed on Emily’s face, “Thank you. We can head out in the morning to collect what I left behind. The Order of Dromos is looking to make their master a god which will cause mass destruction the world and we have to put a stop to it. I have an ally nearby who is likely still alive but it is essential we get the gem that holds his essence so we can destroy it.”

“I assume it is not so simple as taking a large hammer to it,” Sitha could sense this was going to be a lot of trouble he had committed to being involved with this.

“His servants have ways of recapturing his essence available we have to either take it to a temple or perform a ritual to make sure he goes to the Hells where he belongs.”

The lizardfolk nodded before going to sleep for the night trying to process what he had learned and what he should do to keep this over with as soon as possible. Dealing with humans always seemed to create a lot more work than what was planned at the start. They failed to have the single-minded goals of the lizard but perhaps he could use this process to simplify things. Get the gem would be first and after that was accomplished you decided on the next task, why did humans have to make things so complex. It felt awkward going to sleep with these strange extensions on the body but he managed.

Emily didn’t like to have a companion in her body, well, it might not be her body but it felt like her body. It was tempting to try and throw the other spirit out the body so that she wouldn’t have any opposition but Sitha was very ground and attached to the world. She wouldn’t take the body permanently but having to go to a committee for decisions would make her job harder, still, it was better to not have him fight. At least with him in the body, she could wander through the world.

Using the body as an anchor she could explore the world as an astral spirit. The forces of Dromos might have detected she left her prison and would certainly come after her. It appeared many years had passed since her death and she hoped that with those years came to the end of the Order of Dromos. Without their master’s guidance, it might have fallen apart and this would be nothing but a short trip but that was too much to hope for.

Dromos had been born a demigod but he looked to join the pantheon of true celestial beings. He had formed a secret army through the enslavement of others mostly with magic but a few he seduced with offers of pleasure or power. He had started a ritual that was to rise him to the heavens but Emily and a group of others had managed to stop it. Hiding the gem container had taken most of her magical energy and prevent her from protecting herself but she was worried that someone had betrayed her.

Few people knew where she had gone, all of the group that survived had spread far and wide to hide who had the gem. She hadn’t originally been the one with it, Artus, their leader had it but he secretly met her and put it in her care as an extra safeguard. She had been slain without them ever questioning if she had the gem. This would require some investigation into who had survived and she wasn’t sure Sitha would be up for that.
152111113131121.title: Agree

choices: Check into one of the others
1521111131311212.content:
Emily had become a master of magic in life so she knew the astral realm very well and being dead had given her a lot of time exploring how it worked. Unfortunately being dead had also proved difficult in doing everything she wanted, she had been attached to the world by her unfinished business and to the location of her death but things had changed with getting a living body back.

The astral realm didn’t fully look like the real world and there were often more dangers here than there were in the real world. Gods and demons had a greater access to this place and they often looked for stray souls to take and empower them so she would have to be careful and not just rush off after the first line she found.

She reached through the connections she had with others until she found the one she was looking for and stretched out the threads so they became more clear to her. The gem called to her in this realm offering to bring true life back to her but she refused it as she had so many times over the years. Dromos would know and come for her and she would be more vulnerable with the gem attached to her, she would have to remove the enchantments that she had used to hide it.

The gem wasn’t evil, at least it hadn’t been designed to be evil but some god long ago, she suspected one of trickery or jokes was involved, had crafted the artifact to give people what they desired most if they could fill it with the energy it needs, unfortunately, there were a lot of stupid and evil people out there. It would be best if they could just destroy it but she first wanted to find out what had gone wrong.

The first thread she found was of Artus and to her surprise, she found out he was alive after all of this time. How had he managed to survive all of these years? The man was a paladin of legend, had the gods blessed him with an extended life for his service or had he fallen? He had been the one to give her the gem so she didn’t think he was the one to betray her, it could be that he was that he was cursed, perhaps a trap.

She took a deep breath, well not really as she was in astral form there was no use dwelling on what she didn’t know but focus on what she could learn. Emily traced another thread and found that Lucian was still alive as well but instead of focusing on him she went to the final thread. Mercedes and found her thread was dead and had been dead for a long time.

Two of her companions were alive which meant if there was a traitor they were likely still alive which meant it was more important than ever to protect the gem.
1521111131311212.title: Astrally seek out companions

15211113.content:
The bright morning sun shinning through the window awoke the lizardman from his slumber. The healing had progressed well but his body was still sore even after stretching but within a day or two, he should be back to full strength. Sitha decided to make sure he had hidden his trail the night before because he couldn’t be sure he had hidden it well while wounded.

Most of the trail had been well hidden and was likely to go undiscovered by those who tracked him unless they had tracking animals but he had seen none at the fort. It would take them time if they had to hire trackers with animals, valuable time as his scent faded and that was if the animals had a proper source scent to follow. His blood had likely mingled with the blood of the Prince and his other kills at the Fort rendering it less useful but he couldn’t depend on it. He would need to plan defenses of this place and have a way to escape.

Searching the for trails around the place he found them as overgrown as he remembered. Few if any still traveled through this area which suited him fine but there would still be people who would remember stories of this place if they were asked the right questions. He wasn’t certain if he should place traps or not because though he might get a couple of people it would certainly signify to searchers that someone was here.

He decided to leave that question until later as he circled the town looking over buildings trying to determine which ones would be safe to enter and which ones might make a tomb over his head if he wasn’t careful. Sitha didn’t like how most of the buildings swayed when he only put forth a little effort into moving them. There were not many places for him to hide in the town but perhaps he could suggest otherwise. Digging in his clawed feet he marked his passage into the various buildings in town to spread confusion to anyone who might check if he got lucky they might even have a building kill a few, at the very least it should give him some time.

The warrior eyed the remaining buildings and debated searching for the things of interest or if he should do some hunting as his supplies would not last forever. Sitha decided he should head back to his room and continue his plans after dark. His eyes worked better at night than those of the humans who were likely chasing him so working at night would allow him to go unnoticed better if there were any prying eyes around him.

Going to sleep when so much was left undone felt wrong to him but it was best if he was going to stay here awhile but when it got dark he intended to work twice as hard when that time came. For now, he would close his eyes and make plans for tonight while he slept.
15211113.title: Morning

152111132.content:
His food supply was good so it wasn’t a priority but it would be relaxing to hunt after the stress of the last few days. The ground here was not a swamp like he was familiar with and loved instead it was a forest thick with pine trees with a chill to the air he didn’t like. He would be spending a great deal of time out in the sun basking in its warm rays to make up for the chill he was feeling in his bones. The dark night didn’t help with the cold but it was a friend to him and he often shared its embrace on his hunts in the swamp.

Sitha’s keen eyes and nose soon found prey to hunt, a large stag moved through the woods cautious of dangers like him. The buck ears perked up as it heard something out of place but it wasn’t the lizardman. Sitha wished he had brought his sword with him but he had only brought a few spears with him to travel light. If it were some knights seeking revenge for their fallen master he would have to run or take weapons from those he managed to kill.

He aimed a spear at where the deer was looking, no longer concerned about a fresh meal. The deer raced away as the danger approached passing the lizardman who gave it not a glance as he waited for what had frightened the creature. Drow moved through the woods with a disregard for the noise they made as only ones who felt vastly superior to all around them could. They were five in number and armed for war.

The dark elves wore full chain armor save for one, a spell caster by the look of her staff carved with arcane symbols. He wasn’t certain what they were up to but he was very certain he didn’t want to get involved with them. Many things could have brought them to the surface from their dens of evil far beneath the earth, they could be seeking to hunt down their surface-dwelling cousins, hunting down slaves was another option or they could be searching for a foul artifact to add to their collections. None of the options he could think of were good and the lizardman wondered if he could avoid dealing with him as they were heading in his direction. The drow did seem distracted but it wasn’t something he wanted to depend upon.
152111132.title: Go hunting

1521111323.content:
The lizardman decided to stay where he was because though they were talking they had sensitive ears that were likely to detect him if he was to step on some branch on the ground. Sitha pressed tightly against the tree as they came closer. His nose wrinkle at the faint smell of poison lurking on them. It was likely some sort of poison to paralyze their prey so they could enslave them or torture them to death.

Their eyes were even keener in the darkness than his but he prayed they were distracted enough to not notice him. The group passed him causing his heart to beat hard in his chest to the point he was almost afraid they would hear it. They were vulnerable to attack, it was a chance he would not get again. He didn’t know if they were going to be back this way but if they did he was likely to lose to them. Sitha lifted his spear to a position to charge if he could take out a couple he might be able to survive this encounter.

They barely registered hearing the sound of Sitha’s pounding footstep as he rushed forward and plunged the spear through the spell caster and one of the warriors. He released his grip as soon as the second dark elf was speared and brought his jaws shut on the throat of third, enjoying the flavor of fresh meat in his mouth, as he tore the drow’s sword from his hand to face the last two enemies.

A roar of rage filled the air as one of them charged him with a wild swing but the second hesitated in fear at the monster who had already slain three of his companions. The man’s two handed swing was blocked by the stronger lizardman’s single arm as his free hand slashed out to cut the eyes blinding the drow. With practiced blind fighting training, the dark elf continued the fight but his opponent was a skilled warrior as well who only took careful slices from his enemy now that he had taken advantage of the drow’s mistake while keeping a careful eye on last dark elf who was slowly backing away from the encounter.

“Run! Avenge our deaths whelp!” the elder drow yelled as the blade of Sitha struck a lethal blow in his belly. He could only watch as his companion fled, unable to stop the throw of the spear.
1521111323.title: Stay put

15211113231.content:
Sitha was a master of combat and it was vital to end his target before others were informed of what had happened. The sharp tip of the spear true and sent the freshly made corpse to the ground allowing the lizardfolk sometime to relax and think about what he wanted to do next but he made sure to keep some distance from the dying drow in front of him because even in the dying state they could be very dangerous.

The warrior slid to the ground clutching at his stomach, “You have only served to delay us. Others will come and they will bring armies to crush your world. My people will make boots of you and your kind. You are animals to be used and disposed of at our whim.”

Only the drow seemed to retain that confidence in their ability after losing to an opponent but Sitha ignored him as he started to search the corpses. He had risked his life to fight them so he should get some reward out of it. As the drow took his time babbling about how superior he was Sitha stripped them of everything of value taking the spellbook that would surely bring a fortune to him. It would go a long way toward achieving his goal.

“Let go of that book you stupid handbag!” fear finally crossed the dying man’s face, something about the spell book was especially important and valuable. “Or I will see that they curse your spirit for all eternity when they awaken my body to find you.”

“I am tired of your yammering warm blood,” Sitha stalked towards the man. “You assume too little of me, you will talk to no one in this life or the next.”

There were foul ways to make the dead talk but most of them required the skull and he was thankfully still hungry. His jaws ended the noise of the drow and his belly was soon filled with three skulls. He stripped the bodies to make it easier for scavengers to take care of the bodies. The fact that the drow hadn’t called out for others told him that help was far from here so he didn’t need to worry about time but he was uncertain about when their disappearance would be noticed.
