He flipped through the book the spell caster had and was surprised to find that it wasn’t in the language of the elves or Underdark, it was a language far more familiar to him, draconic. The language of dragons was well known in mystical circles and by all of the reptilian races. He had learned to read the words in the schools of the humans. Curious as to why a drow would write in draconic he examined the body closer and saw the markings of a warlock, someone who bound themselves to a powerful entity and would have no need for a spell book. A decision would have to be made.
15211113231.title: A Hit

152111132313.content:
The drows were too close for comfort. If any more lurked about they would eventually come looking for their own. Sitha didn’t trust his senses to protect himself from the silent footsteps of the insidious dark elves. It was better to get the jump on them while he still had the chance. Depending on the number he could fight or retreat.

He moved cautiously through the forest. Sitha found the trail easy to follow but why shouldn’t it be? They felt themselves the masters of any land they tread upon. As a child, he had once witnessed a raid by them. The drow fell that day but not before taking more than their number with them. One of his nest mates had died slowly of their poisons.

Noises of camp life ahead halted the forward movement of the lizardman. It appeared they had slaves with them for the drow would never be this noisy. The heavy footsteps of an armored guard and Sitha rushed to great it.

A shocked look formed on the human’s face but no cry for help got past the dagger in the throat. Slaying the guard put a clock on his discovery but it left him with a path out of here. Some nearby bushes hid the body well as the lizardman stalked close to the camp.

Several cages full of slaves had been erected with the men in one cage, woman in another, and the final cage had children in it. They appeared to be of various races leading Sitha to suspect this was a base camp for raiders. He knew of an entrance to the underdark not far from here where they could be moved to or traded.

It wasn’t hard to spot where the drow lurked. At least five guards waited near a series of black tents. A large magic circle was in the center of the camp with a group of robed figures chanting. From a cage, a large human man was dragged and tossed into the center.

“Please you can’t do this to me I have a family!” the man pleaded with magic users to no avail.

The chanting continued and when he tried to exit the circle a magical barrier prevented the escape attempt. Sitha hated the evil magic the people of the “civilized” races crafted and was tempted to put an end to this ritual.
152111132313.title: Follow the drow's trail

152112.content:
It was best to be cautious, he had struck a wound but prey was at the most dangerous when they were hurt. There would be better times to attack especially with him knowing someone was hunting them, it would make him panicked and paranoid, it was also certain recruits would be a lot more hesitant to join with what he was about to do.

Guards were rushing to protect the Prince which meant they weren’t protecting other things, he rushed to grab a couple of torches and threw them in the hay in the stables before he moved to leave this places. The more problems he caused for them the better, they might close ranks but it would mean the Prince would never get away.

Sitha only went a short distance in the woods before he started to backtrack through the trees, in his hunts he had seen the elves use the trees to great advantage because most species didn’t do a good job of observing the trees, it would allow him to keep close and take advantage of any opportunities that presented themselves.

He strapped himself down and went to sleep resting since he had some time, they wouldn’t be after him until morning unless they were complete fools. Sitha went into a dreamless slumber eager to start the hunt in the morning.

The warrior was careful to react slowly to the sounds that had awoken him, bits of sunlight were trickling in upon his scales. It would have been a pleasant morning if people weren’t seeking his death. He had the urge to move up into more densely packed branches but it would make too much noise, even the armored warriors clanking through the bushes were certain to notice him.

“Can you tell how many there were that attack us last night?” Prince Stephan asked one of the searchers.

“We need to secure the help of a ranger sir,” the man hesitated to give his liege bad news. “None of these men are master trackers, the lizardfolk are good in the wild. We have only found the one set of tracks and they vanish when they reach the woods.”

Prince Stephan slashed a hunk of wood from the tree, “Go hire one, I will gather the men, we need to make plans if we have to move, it will be hard with the loss of so many horses but if this was just a scouting mission we have to be ready to act. If it was just a single lizard I think I know who it is and it is an assassin sent by my Father. We must know as soon as possible, make sure you find out Captain Helm or all of our heads may be hanging from pikes.”

The Captain nodded and went back to guiding the search but he put in an order for a horse so he could go to hire a ranger. Prince Stephan moved back to the fort leaving Sitha to pick his next action.
152112.title: Take the cautious route

1522.content:
The powerful lizard man decided to watch and observe for the best chance to take out the Prince. It would give him a chance for him to think about what to do with the Eye of the Lizard Kings when he got it back for his people. The tales of the power it held varied from the tribe telling the tale but all seemed to agree that it gave the power to challenge even dragons and that was certainly something that he wanted for his people.

Evil dragons took advantage of his people and made them slaves to their whims and gluttony for treasure. Sitha wanted to slay some of them to punish them for some of the lizard people who had died in their service and maybe some of the treasure could help build a better life. The simple living in the swamp could be nice but it was a harsh life because they depended on the swamp to provide them with food and it wasn’t always of a giving nature. The lack of protection from all of the predators and hostile forces of the world was the biggest issue. Swamps weren’t exactly prime building grounds but some walls would be nice.

The journey to the fort was long but he still refused to take a horse because it felt too much like riding your food, luckily there was a raft that went most of the way to the location and his legs were strong enough to get him the rest of the way to the location. Many of the people he encountered along the way stared at him and he could understand their curiosity and fear. Most of them had never seen a lizard man before and all of the teeth and claws didn’t exactly suggest a friend. He did his best to ignore them as he continued on his journey.
1522.title: Observe and await the proper time like the croc...

choices: Break through a gap in crowd
15222.content:
Sitha moved through the small town market looking for some dry meat to purchase but he started to feel uneasy as he saw many of the villagers looking at him with fear and hate. His kind was not often seen this far north so was it just a fear of the unknown or had they some prejudice from the war with the kingdom over two centuries ago. War could build a lasting hate with many people as he knew of many lizard people still bore grudges against humans from ancestors who were killed by humans.

He decided avoiding the hostility was the best so he quickly grabbed some salted meat and dropped more than enough coins to pain for it and started to head away from the market to continue his journey. Sitha winced as a staff slammed hard into his side causing him to spin around to see the danger he was facing. A group of at least ten villagers had gathered as a mob and the numbers were starting to swell.

The weapons they carried were mostly tools and farm implements but they could still be dangerous in enough numbers though he would take a lot of them with him especially considering none of them had any armor on them. Anger was making his bloodthirsty at being attacked when he had done nothing wrong.

“I think I need a new lizard skin for the wall,” a portly man holding a hammer took a menacing step towards Sitha.

“As long as I get to keep the skull,” an unseen person in the crowd called out.

Sitha kept backing towards the exit of the town but they kept following him. He could feel a crowd starting to come towards his back and spared a glance and saw he was being surrounded. Several rocks struck him. A man charged forward with a sledgehammer thinking they had the warrior in front of them powerless. The lizardman slammed the man to the ground and pressed his foot on the throat of a man drawing his blade in case the crowd tried to rush him.

“I only wish to leave,” Sitha hissed at the mob. “I have no desire for bloodshed but I will kill if it means keeping myself safe. I know not what your grudge is but I have done you no wrong.”

He watched as the crowd took a step back from the range of his blade but they made no move to part for him to leave so he didn’t remove his foot from the man’s throat. The crowd was murmuring angrily but he couldn’t determine what they were planning to do yet. Sitha scanned the crowded for weak points to breakthrough if he had to. It did look that several members of the mob were leaving, most likely not wanting to risk the violence the lizardman was threatening but it also meant that those left were likely to not leave unless blood was shed.

“There is going to be no easy escape for you, monster,” a woman holding a large butcher knife threatened.
15222.title: Hostile villagers

152221.content:
Sitha decided it was best to try and reason with the humans if he could, “I am on a mission for King Emeril let me pass and I will be on my way.”

He held high the document bearing the seal of the King for all present to see. Humans place a great deal of value on their papers and rules. The lizardman watched the people closely as he turned slowly letting them decide what they were going to do. He didn’t want them thinking of him as a threat, let them know he meant them no harm.

The crowd wavered in there hostility for fear of the wrath of the King and finally, they started to part before him. They slunk away from his path as he picked up speed making sure that he didn’t hit anyone, there was no need to provoke anyone any further.

“You are just going to let him go!” the woman screamed at the crowd, searching for someone to support her but they no longer had the numbers. “His kind killed my son!”

There was a great desire to yell back that it had been her kind who had slain his Grandfather and Grandmother but there would be no point. Most beings only understood their own pain, it was better to leave her with her grief and maybe in time she would be able to move past it. He was nearly out of the village when he heard the fast footsteps of someone running him down. The woman held the cleaver at the ready as she charged him but Sitha knew she was no threat to him.

She had butchered animals in her shop but he had butchered men and monsters. His scaly hand easily grabbed her swinging arm and twisted it so the blade fell harmlessly to the ground. Silence had fallen over the villagers as they waited for the lizardman to strike. Sitha wondered if they would attack him if he slew the woman, it didn’t matter he had little interest in killing her. His sharp teeth were shown as he opened his mouth wide giving her a good look at the instruments of death.

“Do you wish to die?” Sitha asked. “How many of your neighbors do you wish to die? I will not go down easily, I was not the one to slay your son and I have no wishes to slay any of the children of this village but I will if I must. Grieve for your loved ones as I do for the ones I lost to humans, find the ones responsible and make them pay if you must but I am weary of blood for blood so don’t make me live by your standard.”

He freed her and continued on his way sparing a glance occasionally as he vanished from sight but she just sat and stared at him. Sighing with relief he continued until he could bring the keep of the prince into view.
152221.title: Talk to the crowd

1523.content:
An ambush seemed his best chance to take out the Prince because he was well protected inside the fort and it was likely to get harder to get at him as time went on so the lizardman decided to set up an ambush on the road near the fort. The Prince was likely to take a ride to the local villages to “recruit” people to his cause. Recruiting looked a lot like slavery to the eyes of Sitha but the important thing was knowing where the Prince would be.

There were no patrols of the forest near the fort at night so he worked at night to avoid notice preparing his ambush of his target. The work would be a lot easier if he could get some of the local villagers who hated the Prince to assist him but how could he know who to trust. Gold commanded the minds of many humans even when it was in their best interest to not listen to the shiny golden medal. Perhaps he could go after the prisoners that the humans had taken and get some assistance but it was likely the Prince would realize he was being targeted and become much more cautious about his actions.

Eyeing the large building far from the fort where the prisoners were kept he realized it was vulnerable. The fencing could be jumped over and there were only three guards at night. If he could slaughter the guards and free the prisoners it would slow the progress on the repairs to the fort and force the properly trained knights to go gathering villagers again leaving the Prince more vulnerable. The sun would be up again soon and he could come up with what he wanted to do during the day. It was a mistake to not take a chance when it presented itself.
1523.title: Ambush like the cobra taking down a foe with speed

153.content:
King Emeril had called for an adventurer to search for his the court wizard Arimas who had vanished without living word of his whereabouts. In these times of trouble the King needed the aid of his trusted and loyal magic user. Melis had met the wizard at several court appearances, but she wasn't very familiar with him, but she knew enough to know where to start looking, where else do you look for a wizard but in his tower?

Melis borrowed the key that had been given to the King so she could gain access to the tower without having to break through the enchantments that were protecting the tower. As she reached the tower she placed a prayer of protection on herself just in case. Melis was fairly curious what a wizard tower really looked like, and this would be her first chance as a young adventurer to see inside of one. Her usual quests involved attacking temples dedicated to evil and fighting the living dead given to her by the Circle of Light. This was the first time she had been allowed to pick a quest and she thought assisting the local ruler would help in future relations with the church, so she was especially eager to make a good impression.

The places were organized and clean with everything in the proper place. As she reached the top of tower her piercing blue eyes observed strange laboratory equipment bubbling in a variety of colors in numerous beakers but none of them were overflowing. The shelves were filled with strange books with unfamiliar writing but the most amazing sight was a miniature of a large village which seemed to have little people walking around it.

Which should she investigate?
153.title: Melis Cleric of the Holy Light

choices: Go to the Vale of Dragon
1531.content:
Beakers bubbled and steam with various colored liquids flowing from one container to another even without the archmage being here. She looked over the equipment hoping that something would jump out at her and give her a clue as to where her friend had gone. She had some rudimentary training in potion making but this was far more advanced stuff that she was looking which wasn’t surprising considering he had centuries of experience. However, it was still possible for her to get some information from it.

Melis often wondered why the Archmage had come to work for the King because Arimas had always struck her as a much more gentle soul uninterested in the crafting of a kingdom. His main focus seemed to be discovering the mysteries of the world of magic. As she eyed the equipment it looked like there was a gap in what was going on with the process. It was stuck in a continuous loop. Perhaps if she could test some of the items in the process she would be able to figure out what he had left to look for. There did appear to be some notes that were left out that she could look at and get some information from. Thankfully, they didn’t look to be written in one of the many languages he knew that she didn’t but the handwriting was almost as bad as it being in another language.

It might be dangerous to mess with these unknown chemicals because any mistake could have some very serious consequences so she might want to try something else like checking with the church. The oracle wasn’t far from the capital so it wouldn’t be hard to get to it but it wasn’t always the best idea to use it. There was often a price to pay for the wisdom of the gods and it often wasn’t worth what you got in return.

She knew that he often took retreats to a secluded spot in the Vale of Dragon that she could check out. There was rumored to be a dragon who lived there who tolerated the wizard but things might have changed since she last been there. Melis had never met the dragon and every time she had brought up the subject of the creature Arimas had quickly changed the subject. She had always wanted to meet a dragon because the creature fascinated her but she knew they were very dangerous.
1531.title: The lab equipment

15311.content:
With a heavy sigh, Melis started working with the chemicals to see what was being done with the lab equipment. Thankfully there were a lot of extra books and equipment in a chest for her that she was able to use. The Archmage loved helping others to learn so when he learned of her interest in potion making he had given her a lot of free stuff. The value of the stuff was worth several thousand gold pieces but he just waved her off when she tried to deny the gifts.

She would start with the more expensive and more difficult of the potions because much of the stuff she had seen had been running the last time she was here months ago. He would have shut down the equipment if it was a potion little value. Melis focused on her memory to see if any of the chemicals had started to shift color. One of the beakers that was bubbling had become a brilliant golden color so she took a small sample of the bubbling material and placed it carefully in her own beaker for testing.

It was tedious work trying to decipher the notes but she picked out the easy words for her to figure out to narrow her search. Worry started to fill her because many of the ingredients were worth thousands of gold by themselves. Whatever was being worked on was certainly worth killing for. Melis eliminated to the possibility of a youth potion, immortality potion or the most dreaded of all, the potion to transform someone into a lich. Undead of the foulest and most dangerous nature, liches require a life in order to make the final transformation.

She didn’t want to think it was possible that her friend would take that transformation. Melis knew he was very old and over time the potion that could make you younger faded in effectiveness but to become a lich seemed extreme and hard to believe. The more she thought about it the more of a possibility it seemed. The Archmage always viewed things as an obstacle to overcome and wasn’t death but a challenge to overcome to reach the eternal learning that he desired.

The temptation to smash the equipment was great but she wasn’t certain yet and there would be no taking back what she had done if she was wrong. Looking at the information she had it looked like the potion was nearing completion which worried her. She doubted she could stop her friend if she challenged him but he wouldn’t have the time to start the potion again if she were to smash it.

Perhaps, it was best to test further even though she was reaching the edge of her knowledge. If she was wrong she could be killing her friend by ending whatever potion he was creating. Melis cast a spell to detect evil over the equipment and the stench of it was overwhelming and she had to take a few steps back. The spell was a tool but it wasn’t very precise because certain creatures you use for potions could detect as the evil they used to be. There was some regret in the casting because she now had more worries and concerns.

Taking another look at the notes it looked like it was possible that this potion might not even be for the Archmage. King Emeril’s name appeared to have been written several times in the notes but it was hard to tell why. Was he the source of the ingredients or the final recipient of the results of the potion? His children wouldn’t be happy to hear their Father was planning to extend his rule indefinitely which would explain why several of them had been shipped away lately. Melis had thought it was to help stabilize the kingdom now that they were mostly at peace but there could certainly be a much darker motive.

Her dealings with the King were limited but she knew of the terrible acts that were sometimes committed by his most loyal forces the Crimson Tigers. The young cleric had hoped the next generation would disband them. The idea that he wanted to become the eternal ruler of these lands worried her and she wondered what she should do next.
15311.title: Test the chemicals

153111.content:
The young cleric had a hard choice in front of her and she wasn’t sure what to do. There was too much risk in leaving these chemicals unattended. She needed to get rid of them in case there was an evil purpose to what was going on here. Melis tightened her grip on the mace and swung with all of her might. Containers shattered under her blows spilling and splashing chemicals all over the area extinguishing the flames. If she was wrong she had probably done more damage than she could ever hope to repay and ruined a great friendship.

She held back tears at the sad thought but she still had a quest to complete. Melis would try and explain why she had done it to him and pray he understood. She cleaned up the destruction she had done and put it in the trash, salvaging what she could, which wasn’t much. The cleric sat down and wrote a note in case the Archmage returned while she was gone looking for him. Walking down the stairs she could feel something was off, something wasn’t right. It was possible that it was just her guilt nagging at her but it felt like something more.

Calling on her magic she detected life outside of the tower. This wasn’t unusual, as many people called on the wizard of the tower for help but she thought that people had been informed of the absence of the wizard. A worry came to mind as she contemplated why the people were here, they could be after the treasures locked away in the tower, the tower that she had unlocked. Going on the defensive she put her shield in place and lifted her mace as she moved to the exit to confront the people outside of the tower.
153111.title: Melis smash

1532.content:
Melis figured the books might provide some hint as to what the Archmage was up to in his recent research, but she took extra caution before proceeding because wizards were extra cautious in protecting their books. Whispering a couple prayers protection she proceeded with her investigation jumping as a trap spell lashed out at her defenses, but her protective shield held against the attack giving the young cleric a great deal of relief. Gathering herself she continued looking over the shelves of books to see if anything stood out of the ordinary.

The books were all well label to make the easy to find, from shrinking, to animal transformation the books covered a variety of topics. Thankfully but disgustingly, cleaning did not appear to be in the wizard’s primary skill set so figuring out what he had been looking at recently was easy. It appeared he had been investigating the legend of a gorgon. It would be a dangerous pastime even for the Archmage to go after a gorgon, but perhaps the treasure of the gorgon’s victims had lured him to its lair.

Flipping through the books didn’t take long to discover notes indicating the location of a possible gorgon lair hidden in the sea caves far to the south. It would mean traveling to an unfamiliar lands but her oath to the King loomed large in her head. Information on the gorgon itself was sparse and not knowing your opponent was dangerous. Was it better to head directly to the site, investigate this particular gorgon first, or take some precautions against the gaze of the gorgon?
1532.title: The books

15321.content:
Time was important so she decided to head straight to the location because she understood the general idea of how to fight a Gorgon. You avoid looking it in the eyes and destroy the head so no further people would be harmed by the petrification it could cause even after death. Melis had never fought a creature so dangerous before but her friend was in danger and she wanted to help him.

The Archmage had been like a Father to her ever since she had joined the order as a girl just entering her teens. Her parents lived far from the capital city and couldn’t afford to visit and none of her friends had the aptitude to join the order. It was very lonely those first few months but the Archmage took an interest in her and her studies. They had become close friends over the years and she wanted to repay some of that kindness.

She set her horse to a fast pace but nothing that her stallion couldn’t keep up for hours without rest. Melis was tempted to push the speed and just exchange horses at stops along the way but it was a dangerous practice as many station owners tried to trick inexperience people out of fine animals in exchange for inferior stock. She had no desire to waste time haggling with them and besides Starlight had been a gift to her from the King. The rumor was that his bred had been blessed by unicorns with superior intelligence and strength and she had never found him wanting in either of those categories.

As much as she wanted to carry on exhaustion was setting in and sleep was needed if she wanted to make good decisions. The Way Stations provided comfortable beds and exchanges for horses for travelers. They were run by servants of the King and though they were often not as nice as many inns though they were usually of a very reasonable price. In the opinion of the young cleric, they were very good for the commerce of the Kingdom as they often provide a place to sleep safely in uncivilized areas.

It was a familiar lay out with a large clearing around thick wooden walls with a couple of guards on duty all during the night. They likely wouldn’t be able to help anyone if there was any real danger but they made travelers feel a lot safer.
15321.title: Head to the site

1533.content:
The village was just too fascinating to pass up, so she walked closer to the town to figure out how it worked. The people seemed to go about their business with no notice of the giant staring at them. Melis said a small prayer and was soon granted with being able to see the threads of magic, and the village was covered in a tangle of them that Melis wasn’t able to determine all of their effects. Spells of protection and warding were obvious but she wasn’t sure what a certain spell did, as she leaned to get a closer look a hidden ward struck her sending her flailing backwards to the floor.

Melis shook her head to clear her thoughts and cursed herself for being, so foolish as to think an Arch mage wouldn't have hidden defenses. Luckily it appeared to be a simple stun spell with an alarm attached to it. Well, that is one way to find the Arch mage Melis thought glumly as she tried to sit up, but she found the weight of her armor was starting to hold her back. With a surge of effort she regained her feet only to stumble forward as she realized her feet had become much smaller. Articles of armor dropped to the floor as Melis met up with the floor once again.

It was several minutes before Melis was able to collect herself to find that she was naked and enveloped in darkness. The netting around her was heavy with some sort of metal above it that made the going slow, but it wasn’t long before she entered into the light and realized how dire her situation was. She was now the size of one of the people from the village surrounded by her armor.

“Go to the village and be judged,” appeared in large letters in the air as a staircase on the table leading to the village formed. Going to the village had untold dangers but it was possible to get some answers. The chemicals on the lab or the books on the shelves could offer a solution to her current situation, or make it worse. Finally, she had a potion that could restore her on her horse outside, but at this size it would be quite a distance and possibly dangerous.
1533.title: The village

15331.content:
The village seemed like the place to get some answers she thought as she headed towards it. Going to the village would hopefully signal the Archmage who should come to check out what had happened and she would be able to end this mystery. It was embarrassing to walk naked but there was no clothing in sight of her. She tried to cover her generous bosom with one arm as she walked to prevent some of the jigglings as she went up the stairs. As she walked up the stairway the steps vanished behind her, she wasn’t sure if it was an illusion or real but she decided to continue on with her journey and not worry about it. Mages had a habit of messing with reality to scare other people and it was usually best to ignore it.

Melis arrived at the top of the stairs and saw an amazing array of brightly colored buildings and thankfully there was a set of robes for her to put on. The cloth felt wonderful against her skin as she made her way to open the door to the village. She hesitated as she walked to the door because she suspected once it shut behind her it would not open again. With a heavy sigh she decided if she had gone this far why not a go all the way.

The door hissed as it opened and she stepped through and as she predicted it slammed shut behind her. She walked out into the empty streets wondering if she was the only one here. There seemed to be some sort of countdown clock in the sky above. It looked like there was still an hour until whatever event was going to occur so she might have some time to explore this village.
15331.title: The village

15333.content:
Melis decided it would be best to retrieve her antidote from her horse Sunfire, because she didn’t know what dangers protected the lab or bookshelves, and she knew the village had spells to keep the residents inside it and she didn’t want to be stuck in a possibly hostile environment. Now, all she needed to decide was how to go about it.

Not for the first time was she frustrated with her large breasts as they jiggled with her movements. Melis didn’t want to be ugly but looking like a royal pleasure woman was frustrating with how she was treated by many of nobles. Clothing was essential for her modesty even if no one was around, so she went to her satchel to look at her scrolls holding her breasts tight to prevent their movement. She hated to loose a scroll but she wanted to cover up, so the sacrifice of a scroll of minor healing. It felt more like wearing a towel, but some support was better than none.

As she collected herself and started to head for the stairs she saw a black rat maneuvering towards her. It was easily twice her size and its teeth didn’t look friendly. With a quick prayer a searing holy light flashed from her hand leaving a scorched rat corpse, but to her dismay she saw at least five other rat starting to head her way. She could try to make a run for the stairs but that would leave her out in the open, or she could make a dash for a hole in the wall where she could fight the rats one at a time, however the hole spoke of untold dangers, and might not lead down the tower.
15333.title: Get the antidote

153331.content:
Melis decided the stairs were her best bet for safety was the stairs, because if she was fast enough she could make it to safety in time was the theory. The reality turned out to be very different than her theory as the rats quickly outpaced her movements and surrounded her and began to edge closer to her.

With a quick prayer the young priestess summoned forth a a spiritual mace made of holy energy and launched herself at a rat striking a deadly blow on the skull ending it’s life instantly but she only had a moment to plan her next action as the rats launched a counter attack against her. She felt the hot breath of a rat as her training kicked in sending her weapon violently crashing in the neck of the beast snapping it in several place. Melis wanted a few moments to collect herself but they weren’t to be had as one of the final three creatures launched into the air slamming her body to the floor knocking her head against the causing her to lose the concentration on maintaining her spiritual weapon.

Fear began to enter her mind as the danger grew as she watched her weapon fade from reality. She pressed both of her legs against the rodent and kicked as hard as she could sending it sprawling backwards into its’ companions. Hope swelled in her that she might be able to call forth lightning to end the lives of the remaining rats.

The rodents were scrambling to their feet faster than the priestess would have liked, but she paid no attention as the spell she was summoning required complete focus. Evan as the incisors of a rat dug into her thigh her concentration held. The air crackled as lightning slid through the air striking home against the rats ending their lives.

Melis wanted to collapse in exhaustion but many dangers lurked in this tower and certainly more now that she was tiny. She eyed the small of wound on her leg and wondered if she should use a minor or major healing spell on it. Rodents were know for carrying diseases much less what one from a wizard’s tower could be carrying, but the combat had exhausted a lot of her magic and at her size she couldn’t use any of her items to compensate for the loss of magic and strength.
153331.title: The stairs

choices: An Enemy comes forth against the Kingdom of Dar
1533311.content:
Melis decided to only use a a minor healing spell on the cut because it wasn’t that serious and she wasn’t sure how many more rats lurked in the walls. A small pray made the bite vanish without even leaving a scar. She quickly moved to the stair case which would lead to the removal of the condition she was under.

There was no easy way down the stairs for someone who was only six inches tall. A straight drop caused her breasts to jiggle mercilessly. The second step down wasn’t much better as she slid down with her chest pressed against the cold stop. After a few more steps she paused her descent to decide if there was a better way.

Her thigh began to itch and she began to scratch it mindlessly as she contemplated if she should risk more magic to ease the journey down the stairs, but before she could make a decision she felt a heat begin to spread through her body. It was pleasant at first but it was unnatural, it was likely an indicator of the activation of a magical spell. Melis began to say the greater healing spell but all that came out was, “Squeek!”

The pain crackled through her body causing her to fall to the ground on her hands and knee. Melis yanked the scrap of scroll from her body leaving her naked. Every attempt to utter the spell was interrupted by further painful transformation. A long tail sprouted from her body, followed by her jaws extending as sharp incisors started to form in her mouth, and fur began to cover her naked body. Breasts that had once drawn the stares of many men shrank into her body as 10 more pairs of nipples began to form along her body.

It didn’t take long for a female rat to be standing where the young cleric had been. Vocal cords that might have said a counter spell were no longer available to her and her mind had altered to new needs, wants and desires. She could smell the other rats in the tower and knew they would be coming for her shortly but no fear entered her mind as the heat in her lower region was calling out for them. Soon she would more than replace the rodents she had killed.

Crawling up the steps to the top of the tower with her new clawed feet was easy and it didn’t take long for her to scurry across the floor as her tail whipping the air. Male rats rush to meet her and were warm in their greeting licking her genitals sending pleasure coursing through her body. She stood still waiting for the first male to mount his place of honor and she didn’t have long to wait as the largest male pressed his long penis into place slowly thrusting back and forth into her while holding in place with his incisors on the scruff of her neck. Sperm flooded her womb seeking out her eggs to fertilize the eggs. It was over in less than a minute but she wouldn’t have to long to wait for the pleasure to return as another male lined up behind her.

The former virgin wasn’t sure if she was pregnant, but it wouldn’t be for lack of trying.
1533311.title: Minor Healing Spell

15333111.content:
Garl Stonebeard sucked down the ale he had ordered, “Hey, wench get me an ale, perhaps something a little stronger than this piss that you have mistaken for beer.”

The woman frowned at him but went to fulfill his order and the bartender poured something extra in the dwarf’s beer in payment for the insult to his personal brew and Garl was interested in seeing how badly he had hurt the man’s honor. With a big smile on his face at the bartender who met his gaze with a wicked smile. Garl poured the entire mug down his throat ignoring the intense burn of the hot sauce the bartender had placed in it. The bartender looked shocked at the lack of reaction which brought laughter to the grizzled old dwarf. He liked it when someone had the brass ones to stand up to him and liked it even better when he still beat them.

Tossing enough coins on the table to pay his bill and give a healthy tip to the waitress he stepped out into the freezing mountain air. His once black as coal beard was looking much more like the freshly fallen snow on the ground these days but he felt he still had a few good fights left in him. Garl walked confidently down the road not even bothering to have his ax at the ready in case of danger. He wasn’t seeking some glorious death in battle but he had long lost any fear of death he might have had, Garl had lost many companions over the years together and he longed to see them again. If enemies came he would fight them with all of his skill and experience because giving up, allowing himself to fade into the night would be a dishonor to all who had made sacrifices to keep him here.

Pounding hooves approached him along the road causing him to wonder who was in such a hurry to die to break their neck riding a horse so fast during the night. The rider passed the elderly dwarf who watched with mild interest and suddenly the rider spun his animal around and trotted up to Garl.

“Are you Garl Stonebeard the Defender of Beacon Pass?” the courier asked holding out a letter to him.

“I have been called that,” Garl grab the letter and tossed the man a coin and continued his journey with no destination in particular. It looked like the King was requesting help . . .
15333111.title: Another Hero for the Kingdom

15333112.content:
Captain Hector eyed the port of Rising Harbor with hate from his vessel because it was where his father had been killed long ago. Several gibbeted pirates hung outside the walls of the harbor warning Hector and those of his ilk who were caught by the citizens of the Kingdom of Dar but the Captain was determined to have his prize if he could.

He entered the small row boat with nine of his men and started rowing ashore. If everything went according to plan he would have a sky ship by the end of the night. Hector looked over his men wondering how many would make it out of this journey alive because the ship was sure to be guarded and he had to expect there would be some casualties. He only needed four men besides himself to make it out alive from this mission because that was the minimum needed to get the ship moving out of the harbor, any fewer and things would take way too long and they would soon be swarmed by guards.

It had been clever to disgust the crafting of sky ships as a normal shipyard but a lot of bribes in the right places had gotten him the information he had desired. With a sky ship under command, the entire kingdom would be his to plunder. In time he would bring these lands to their knees and he would be as merciful with them as they had been with his Father.

King Emeril had labeled his Father a traitor to the kingdom after he had followed the orders of the ruler he trusted and been executed for his loyalty. All the money and property owned by his family had been taken, leaving Hector and his Mother to the less than tender mercies of the streets. Hector had grown up hard and fast but not quick enough to save his Mother from the ravages of disease that could have been treated if they had had the money.

It was amazing that Hector had attained the title of Captain over several pirate ships at the age of twenty but he intended far greater things and his pirates believed in him and his chances of success. Every success added to his reputation and brought more and better people to work for him but failure would be the death knell for his revenge because pirates didn’t back losers.

There was no moon out this night allowing them to move with greater stealth as they took potions that would give them dark vision for the rest of the night. The compound appeared to be lightly guarded but Hector suspected it was just cover to hide the truth of the valuable property they protected. The pirates would have to work quickly and try to block any alarms from being sounded because when the city guard got involved the numbers would quickly turn against them even if they had superior skill. Setting two of his best archers to secure their escape route if things went bad quickly and headed towards the entrance.
15333112.title: An Enemy comes forth against the Kingdom of Dar

153331121.content:
The pirate had learned long ago that striking fast often won the day. All they really needed to do was steal the ship, it wasn’t like they were going to stick around and hold the port hostage. All he wanted was the ship, at least for now.

“Alright,” he smiled at the boarding crew. “It is time to separate the men from the ladies.”

“If I were a lady I might take offense at that comment,” Cali pulled out her short sword.

“You have to show her that you have bigger balls than her. At least do that for me.”

“Fat chance with this lot.”

Several of them chuckled and elbowed each other as they drew their weapons. These were some of his finest people, he had handpicked them for this mission. They were not as bloodthirsty as so many who found their way to this field of work. Brandishing their weapons with a few quick sword strokes would be enough, he didn’t want them getting into a prolonged fight.

Several loud explosions lit the night sky attracting the attention of the guards. Most of them didn’t even notice the pirates until they saw them cutting the ropes.

“You can’t be up there!” a shined a beacon lantern on them.

“Are you kidding me,” Roger muttered as another rope fell away. “I am not asking for archmages or anything as guards but seriously get a clue buddy.”

“Pirates at work go away!” Hector shouted. “There does that make you feel better.”

“Much.”

“How are you coming, Lenna? I don’t mean to rush you but they may have realized we don’t belong here.”

A crossbow bolt flew past his head for emphasis but the elf mage didn’t react. Her concentration was on overriding the controls but sharp words would be had later from her. She didn’t seem able to take her stick out of her butt but she had an essential job.

“Don’t stand there!” a captain of the guards appeared with reinforcement cutting down their time table. “Get aboard the ship and arrest them!”

Roger smiled as he saw the man made no attempt to come aboard the ship himself. The vessel creaked to life lifting them into the air.

“I would love to stay and talk but I have places to be,” his crew cheered as the guard fell to the hard stone below. Hector took the helm and steered away from the port only taking time to pick up his snipers.

This prize was worth a fortune and would set them up for a long time to come if they sold it. They would not be happy to hear that he was thinking of doing other things, grander things. It would be difficult to win them over because most were after instant gratification.

Where should he go?
153331121.title: Strike fast

1533311211.content:
Sheer cliffs appeared ahead of them as dawn started to peek over the horizon. Docks reached out into the empty air. Far below he could see his ship Bella’s Hope waiting for him in the waters below. Three other ships were docked at the pirate port with life bustling even this early in the morning. The holds were being loaded for new trips or pirates were in a hurry to sell their goods so they could enjoy the fruits of their criminal behavior.

“What if I told you I was thinking of not selling this ship?” Captain Hector turned to Cali.

“I would say you promised the crew a major score, you haven’t exactly been filling the holds with gold and silver,” concern filled her face. “What hair-brained scheme are you thinking of trying to accomplish?”

“We could be so much more than simple pirates barely scraping by.”

“Unless you want a knife in your spleen I would suggest you cut the sales pitch and get to the point.”

“I have two options, option one we go after the Castle of Queen Nazara. The second option we start forming an armada, we could bring back the pirate kings and queens of the days of yore. Which one do you think I could sell to the crew easier?”

“Let me think. The first one involves going to an island with a nest of ornery wyverns to find a place that may or not exist. Even if it does exist we don’t know if it is still functional yet it still has more chance than your second choice. Armadas require money which we don’t have and it requires captains to show a modicum of teamwork which I have yet to see.”

“If there is enough money involved . . .”

“You will just have more blades stabbing into your back.”

“Herzod has said he would be willing to give us a loan which will buy us time for the crew to come around.”

Cali rushed in and kneed him in the balls dropping him groaning to the deck. She piloted the ship into docks and waited for the captain to recover.

“I take it you don’t think dealing with him is a good idea.” Hector struggled to his feet.

“He will make a loan with anyone but makes sure they are forever in his debt. Do you want a slave collar around your neck because I sure don’t. It is good to have dreams but let us just sell the ship and see where that takes us.”

“We might never get a chance at another skyship.”

“Than sell Bella’s Hope, it will be less of a profit but you won’t have a mutiny on your hands.”

“Perhaps you are right.”

He didn’t know if he could sell Bella’s Hope, it had been his Father’s ship even if he did sell it wouldn’t be long before he tried to get it back. The attractions of town didn’t call him as they usually did. Trollops and whores pressed their wares against him but he just pushed past them. The shouts and screams of the gambling parlors held no sirens call only the business district had what he want.

It was far quieter here, even the most notorious pirates didn’t dare steal from these men but the foolish and desperate would still try. Fearsome guards stood by to make them think twice. Shops for buying an selling all goods were available it was now time to pick the future for him and his crew.
1533311211.title: Parrot's Peak

153331123.content:
Watching closely for movement in the shipyard he saw far too much movement. The shipyard closed down at night with only a couple of workers staying late for work and a couple of guards patrolled the yard. Numerous figures seemed to be peeking out from behind cover looking for something and he had a strong idea that they were looking for him. He had been betrayed by someone and that worried him more than the men in front of him. Hector had come out on top against long odds, they would be closing on a trap on him and that most likely meant they had divided their men.

If he pushed forward with enough force he might be able to get the ship and get it flying out of this trap. It would be a tale of great daring if it succeeded but the odds were certain to be against him but weren’t they always when you were a pirate.

“We have been betrayed men,” Captain Hector quickly motioned for them to be quiet before they started to express their anger or fear. There was no time for those emotions. He didn’t know how tightly they were surrounded or how quickly the trap would be sprung. “Don’t worry about raising the alarm just head for the ship. They will be focused on capturing or killing me so I will divert their attention and you get that ship in the air. If that works, drop a rope to me and if all goes well I will climb aboard and we will be searching for the traitor soon enough.”

The men weren’t happy at their prospects but they were happy that the Captain would be taking the brunt of the attack and not them. Captain Hector prayed to any God that would listen that there weren’t men already aboard the ship guarding it.
153331123.title: Problem

1533311232.content:
Captain Hector smiled as he saw the people hesitated when they saw him dash away from the other pirates. Any delay was a good thing for him and his mean, a bolt narrowly missed him and exploded with a cloud of glittering dust which told him they were trying to capture him not kill him and he hoped his crew was getting the same treatment. He darted behind some boxes as he decided his next move.

“Surrender and you won’t face the death penalty!” General Narn screamed over the area. The man’s voice had come from the ship they were trying to take and the pirate knew the trap was complete.

There would be no victory this day if a powerful leader of the king’s armies was here. He didn’t realize the King viewed him as such a threat and was a little flattered by it if more than a little frustrated there would be no victory this day. Death would serve no one this day so he did the only thing he could, live to fight another day.

“Give up men, we don’t have a chance!” Captain Hector yelled to his men as he tossed out his weapons. He kept a few items pocketed and hidden on his person but he doubted that he would keep them for long. If General Narn The Destroyer was here they were not taking any chances and would be looking for any tricks or secrets the pirates would have on them.

He was pleased to see that his men were obeying him and much happier about there being no slaughtering of his crew. They were being cuffed and led away as a group of guards surrounded him but none took an effort to close in on him as it looked like the General wanted to put the manacles on him personally.

“It is a great honor to be captured by such a beautiful woman,” Captain Hector stared into the dark eyes of the small dark-haired general.

“Pirates are a plague on this land and I would see you dead,” the manacles clicked into place and he felt a chill going down his spine from the war mage’s words. She would kill him if he got the chance so he would have to wait for an easier guard to make his escape. “But the King has another purpose for you.”

“It is so nice to feel wanted. May I be so bold as to ask what it is?”

“You may but you will not get an answer from me.”

He was escorted away from his men to a carriage that raced away from the port taking quick twists and turns. The pirate tried to keep track of where they were but it was impossible with the hood over his head but he knew it was the better part of town as he felt the carriage go up hills. He didn’t bother trying to work on the manacles because he heard Narn talking to the driver and knew she was with him. She could kill him in any one on one battle that would come up so he focused on the nobles they would be taken to.

It had to be one that was powerful and influential who wouldn’t want the company of a pirate leader known about. He sniffed the air outside of the carriage as he was dragged from the carriage and got his answer from the rich aroma of Crimson Orchids. An expensive flower to keep in this climate and he knew of only one person who kept the flower. The Duke of White Manor, a powerful man who was a great threat to the King with his money and power. The hood was yanked from his head.

“The package is delivered,” General Narn said as she held out a parchment to the Duke.

Dark glee filled the face of the man as rushed through the reading of the parchment before signing, “Be on your way I and my guest have things to do.”

A grunt of an agreement was given as the general turned and left slamming the door behind her. There were dark rumors about the pleasures this noble took part in and he hoped the man had other reasons for securing him but he didn’t know what they could be. The man was more than a little mysterious only rarely appearing outside on rare occasions but the strange collection of people and creatures that came and went from the place spoke of dark dealings possibly with cults, or treason no one was really certain but with his heavy control over shipping and transportation he certainly had reason to have a grudge against pirates interrupting his services.
1533311232.title: The trap springs

15333112322.content:
Duke Nicholas Crest of White Manor’s people led him into a room as Hector tried to figure out if there was a way out of this. The servants looked like they were trained warriors because of how they moved but he couldn’t see any weapons on their bright white uniforms. They gently planted him on a couch and moved to either end of the room to wait for any further orders. It was likely they were some sort of monk who could crush his body the instant he tried to go against their master.

“You have cost me a lot of money,” the Duke sat behind a desk as if this was some sort of interview. “Being the generous person I am, I want to know how you intend to repay me for these losses.”

There was a temptation to say something rude to the man but that was certain to not get him out of here, “I have some treasure stocked up but I doubt that it would be enough to tempt you and my ship and crew have been taken so why don’t you make me an offer and I will see if I am willing to make a deal.”

“I knew that you were the right person, intelligent enough to ask about the deal and wise enough to know you might not be willing to pay the price. I am seeking an heir and you are the right kind of stock for that, you have a bit more recklessness but you haven’t had the proper education.”

“How do you propose I provide you an heir?” he doubted the man was planning to give his fortune and he couldn’t remember any daughter being spoken of. An unpleasant thought formed in his mind that magic would be involved and he would be the one bearing the children.

He opened a small box revealing a beautiful blue gem on a beautiful gold necklace, “You shall make lovely children after the necklace has done its work upon you.”

“What if I refuse?”

“Oh, if you refuse, I shall put a much different necklace and bracelets upon you and we play a much different game. Honestly, I am willing to do either, one brings the joy of a child to mold into a child who could one day rule the kingdom more than paying me back for the losses you made for me and the other provides me with a game that shall give me my revenge and could still give me the heir I desire.”

Duke Crest opened a second box that had a slave collar and bracelets for the wrists and the and the ankles. He knew that there would be a great deal of magic in them, Hector could see the servants watching him closely for an attempt to escape.

“I don’t suppose you could make refusal any better for me because no offense you aren’t exactly my type,” Hector knew he was delaying for a time but his hands and legs were still bound. He worked at the knots but he wasn’t sure it would help.

The noble rubbed his chin, “There should be a reward if we are going to play a game. If you choose to turn back into a man after a year I shall give you the money for a ship and crew but if you don’t want to turn back into a man, well, I will have my reward.”

The pirate captain could feel the ropes on his hands loosening.
15333112322.title: A touch of magic

153331123222.content:
Even if he managed to get loose how was he supposed to deal with the warriors without a weapon, his eyes scanned the room for weapons he could use to even the odds. Swords and axes were attached to the walls at various spots, he might be able to use them, he just hoped they weren’t ornamental.

The slave collar would take care of the Duke, it would serve the man right for trying to turn him into a bride. It was worth the chance he decided he wasn’t going to go down like a bitch to some rich entitled noble. “Our entertainment has been interrupted so it is only right you provide us some entertainment in return. We have many games you can participate in. All we ask is you join us for one.” The smile never reached the eyes of the baroness. There was a trap here.

“What sort of games are you talking about?” Narra narrowed her eyes.

“Only simple ones because we are simple people. Hide and go seek, a run to the edge of the woods, or an archery contest. I bet you would be really good at that one.”

“I don’t suppose you would let me in on the rules of your special games?”

“Where would the fun be in that? But I tell you what, if you win the game you play I will give you a surprise bonus gift.”

“Wonderful, I don’t suppose I can refuse to play any of the games?”

“It is far too late for that.”
15422.title: Make a deal

1543.content:
The bonus weighed heavily on her mind, so Narra decided to go after Princess Penelope. She was familiar with the appearance of the princess by the speeches she had attended. The woman had lovely chestnut hair braided down to her rear. She had just come to full womanhood and had bright green eyes that had started to draw suitors to her. The young lady had vanished on a trip to meet with a potential foreign suitor, but the man had never shown up and she had disappeared on her way back. For some reason, the King had refused to tell her who the suitor was but if she needed to she would find out who the person had been.

She dreamed of the success and the rewards it would bring to her people. Narra was so close and every coin she could get a hold of went to the goal. She couldn’t fail when she was this close. Narra knew where the Princess had last stayed so she would work back from there.

A storm cloud was rumbling towards the inn as she arrived at the Dragon’s Nest. The building looked ominous in the flashing lightning. Narra wondered if she should stay at the inn or continue with her habit of living in the woods to save money. She would have a better chance of learning more if she stayed in the inn but it would also announce her presence to anyone remaining in the area involved with the kidnapping.

The elf watched as the guards circled the large structure looking for any trouble makers who might be lurking and it made her wonder how the Penelope had been captured with body guards around her. Perhaps they had been drugged at the inn, so the people had passed out on their journey home.
1543.title: Princess

15433.content:
Narra decided she needed to have a look inside but she didn’t want anyone to know she was here yet. An organization that could take down a Princess might be very large and very powerful so she had to be careful. She was very familiar with poisons and herbs, so if there were any hidden in the kitchen she should be able to find them.

She took the time waiting for darkness to set up camp and have a few edible plants so she wouldn’t get hungry. There would be no campfire this close to the inn in case the guards came to investigate. As soon as she felt able to hide in the shadows she slipped away from her camp and headed towards the inn. The moon was only half full but the light was more than sufficient for her eyes.

The guards didn’t break up their routines, so it was easy to time their passage and slip through unnoticed under the cover of darkness. She watched closely the inner courtyard which had many more lanterns to light it and few places for cover. Thankfully, the guards appeared to be more interested in talking than patrolling.Narra found that luck favored her when she felt right in her actions. Her master had often laughed at the thought because he believed only doing your job and he believed that if things were easy it was because someone wasn’t doing their job.

She peered through the window of the kitchen and saw they were finishing up the cleaning of the kitchen before they left for the night. The elf was glad she had taken training in the art of lock pick and her nimble fingers opened the simple lock. Odors of many spices and foods struck her nose but she needed to find out if there was something more here than delicious food being cooked up.
15433.title: Sneak in to investigate

154333.content:
The ranger moved carefully through the room checking bottles and containers for anything out of the ordinary but she was disappointed to discover nothing. Not everything could go easily, she thought about pushing her luck and looking for other places things could be hidden when she noticed something out of the ordinary along the wall. Narra probed the wall with her dagger and discovered a switched which pressed before stepping back and drawing her short sword.

A slight click could be heard as the secret door slowly swung open revealing a passage leading down into the unknown. Lanterns lit the way down but she was cautious about heading down because she hated closed in places. Her desires told her to back out and watch for a few days so she could figure out the comings and goings of the people down this tunnel. She would know more about who was involved and how many but going down these stairs would always be a risk. The longer she waited the more chance she had to be discovered. Going now was her best chance to get in and out without being spotted.

She decided to take a little more risk and quietly went down the stairs closing the secret door behind her. Narra listened closely for the sounds of any people but she didn’t hear anything so she continued to the bottom of the stairs. The sounds of chains reached her keen ears and she wondered if would be able to free some prisoners but she would have to be extra cautious because where there were prisoners there were usually guards.

Following the sound she had heard, she discovered a room with a small cell at the back a room with a guard facing the cage laughing as the prisoner tried to grab their food that was just out of the person’s reach.

“All you have to do is take off your clothing and the food is yours,” the guard laughed.

“Never,” came the response. “Your bosses won’t let you starve me to death!”

“True but you going a few days without food won’t bother them. You could be so much more comfortable if you gave me a little more sugar.”

The fine elf blade severed the man’s head from his body silencing him from warning others. She gazed into the hallway to make sure no one else was coming before closing the door to hide her activities. Narra went to grab the keys and free the prisoner.
154333.title: Find a secret passage

1543333.content:
It was one of the guards of the princess, Ella, was locked in the cell. It would be nice to have some help if things didn’t go well, so Narra quickly unlock the cell and the warrior went to work stripping the guard of his gear before taking a chowing down on the food on the table. The elf watched the door carefully, knowing how hungry she must be she didn’t want to strain the guard if she didn’t have to.

“Do you know what is going on here and where the Princess is?” Narra asked when Ella had finished eating.

“The empire is involved, there was supposed to be a marriage to seal an alliance but we have been betrayed. We were ambushed but I don’t think they work for the empire because of the dress and strange symbols I didn’t recognize that they wore. I was separated from the Princess and I don’t know if she is still here or has been taken somewhere else.” Ella answered. “I don’t know if there is a traitor in the empire or they were the main culprit in this but I aim to find out and rescue the Princess.”

“Are up to exploring the rest of this place or should I escort you out of here? I want an honest answer because this is dangerous enough and I don’t want you collapsing on me if things get bad here.”

“I admit I am not at my best right now but I am still more help than a hindrance. If there is a chance of saving the Princess I won’t be left behind.”

Narra wasn’t sure how honest the guard was being but she didn’t have time to continue arguing. She didn’t know if or when guard changes would occur, so she needed to explore the rest of this place before her kill was discovered.
1543333.title: A Guard!

15433333.content:
The arrow scored a direct hit into the eye socket ending the life of the temple guard causing the man’s partner to draw his blade just in time to be stuck into the wall as a crossbow bolt slammed into the body ending the life with a small grunt. Narra had never been one who was big on religion but she recognized the symbols as something very old and dark. There were scenes of women being bathed in some sort of light and were gone. She wished she had studied her history more so she understood better what she was dealing with.

“It appears to be some sort of temple,” Narra peered into the room and saw a large room with a woman strapped down to a table under the largest crystal the elf had ever seen. “Do you recognize the symbols or what sort of temple this is?”

Ella shook her head, “I don’t know what god or goddess this place is dedicated to but we need to get to that woman and get her out of here.”

The woman’s face was covered as a part of some ceremonial outfit, so it might be the missing princess. Whoever she was, Narra intended to rescue her if she could. She listened closely to see if she could hear anything occurring in the room. The faint sound of chanting could be heard by her sensitive ears. There was a group of people nearby and she suspected they would be entering the room soon.

“We need to move fast or slow,” Narra said to her companion. “I hear some chanting and I suspect some sort of ceremony is going to start soon so we need to act quickly or wait here to ambush them. If we get caught in there we are going to have a lot of trouble getting out so what is your choice?”
15433333.title: A temple

154333331.content:
“I hate waiting,” Ella said. “You rush and get the girl and I will cover you from here. I don’t want you to worry about me keeping up with me. I am good with a crossbow and I will give you a whistle if I spot someone.”

Narra gave a slight nod of acknowledgment as she silently raced across the room. Her honest preference was to wait in an ambush when she knew people were around but it was perhaps better to try and get the girl out of here before something bad could happen to her. The woman was bound with rope that gave way easily to the sharp elven blade of the ranger. As she helped the woman up she spotted the cultists entering the room.

“Run!” Narra screamed to the girl as she switched to her bow and started to deliver death with the weapon.

A crossbow bolt ended the life of one of the cultists getting too close for comfort. She slung her bow onto her back and raced after the woman she had freed as the numbers of the cultists started to swell beyond her ability to kill. Ella was suddenly tossed into the room knocking the sacrifice to the ground but the elf easily leaped over them and drew her blades to hand as she attacked the large black armored figure in front of her.

There was power in the person’s attacks but they were slow and clumsy in the movements. The person was almost like a drunk but was most likely under the mind control of the cultists. She didn’t have time to worry about freeing this person from the control of the cult, especially with the other enemies closing the distance. Her blades darted in quickly to vulnerable parts of armor dropping the man to the floor, dead or dying she wasn’t sure.

“Take her and go!” Ella screamed as she tried to push back the mob. Narra had always respected the sacrifice people were willing to do for others and she just hoped it wasn’t in vain as she took the arm of the unknown woman. She had seen the quivering of the muscles on the guard of the princess and she suspected it wouldn’t be long before she was knocked to the ground. The ranger closed the distance to the door when a flash of light from the giant crystal shot toward the group. She had been curious about what the crystal did but she happened wanted to be a test subject of it.
154333331.title: Move quickly

1543333311.content:
Narra was too busy holding back the tide of cultist to be worried about the magical gem in the center of the room and what it was going to do. Every second she held up the people was more time for the princess to get somewhere safe but it looked like her time was up as she was struck by the light of the gem.

She suddenly felt very weak and she dropped to her knees as the people backed away from her. The elf tried to get up but she found she stumbled forward out of her boots. Her clothing was becoming loose on her body and it didn’t take long to figure out she was shrinking. Forgetting about any sense of modesty she slipped out of her clothing so she could race for cover but as the ray shut off the cultist rushed forward after her and there was little chance of a six-inch elf escaping full-size people even if she was fit so she went to delay them even more.

Leaping from the snatching grasp of a diving person she raced for the pile of bodies she had produced in her fighting to hide. She crawled into the sleeves of one of the cultists uncomfortable to be naked next to a corpse but she had little chance of escaping but she could delay them further she thought with a smile.

“Get the elf, she is to be given to Sultay in the place of the princess!” A voice screamed. “If we don’t have something to be given to Sultay tonight there will be hell to pay!”

She could feel the bodies being shifted near her as she searched her mind but failed to find anything on a Sultay. Was it god, demon, or something else? Narra hoped she wouldn’t find out by meeting the being.
1543333311.title: Transformation

choices: Look for a place to hide
1543333313.content:
The elf decided they must not have had a lot of practice with the crystal because they ended up hitting many of their own people resulting in them vanishing leaving only piles of clothing behind on the floor. Shrieks and screams of fear filled the area as the people scatter to avoid being hit by the crystal. Narra took aim and unloaded a couple of arrows into the people holding Ella and hoped that would give her a chance to escape with them and the elf turned her attention back to the escape route.

She didn’t know how long the crystal would take to recharge and she had no intention of finding out as she exited the room as quickly as her feet would carry her. The woman she had rescue was cautiously moving down the hall towards the exit when her head jerked around when she heard Ella running out of the room. Penelope removed the head covering, revealing herself to be the princess they were looking for but they didn’t have time celebrate as the cultists had found their courage and were giving chase.

Narra waved the guard past her down the hall so she could block the doorway. The narrow entry point would allow her to mitigate the superior numbers of the enemy, especially as they stumbled over the dead bodies she was creating. Eventually, some of them would try to come around the other way and flank them or even come around through the inn if there was another entry point to it and she would be captured but hopefully the princess would be far from here when that happened.

The cultist started to grow more cautious as their numbers dwindled before the deadly twin blades of the ranger. They started to pull bodies out of the way as they fell before someone took the place of the corpse. She wished they would take longer in doing it so she would have a chance to rest before fighting another opponent but they kept coming like the endless waves of the Great Selac Sea. The sound of people coming from the side hallway turned the elf’s thoughts to the more than likely chance that she would be captured or killed soon.

A dwarf might be happy at setting his death price so high and continue fighting to the end but elves placed a far greater value on life. She still had a chance at escape and she hoped that she could make it.
1543333313.title: Miss!

15433333132.content:
Narra decided hiding would give her companions the best chance of escape as the enemy divided attention to pursuing both groups. She was very good at hiding and her magical cloak would help a great deal so she headed down the enemies coming from the side hallway, easily dodging them as they were shocked by her approach and went into the unknown beyond the doorway.

She slammed her door shut behind her and shut the lock before taking in the new environment. It looked like there was a limit to the number of cultists after all because she was alone at the top of a set of stairs. The elf moved quickly knowing that it wouldn’t take them long to find the key or come around the other way so she searched for a place to hide as she worked her way deeper into the complex.

Her sensitive ears could hear people racing through the room with the large crystal so she picked up her pace to block their entrance to where she was located. Two guards blocked her objective so she threw a dagger into the throat of one and dodged past the guard of the second burying her sword into the man’s chest releasing her grip as she jumped for the doorway shutting it with force on the first of many cultists trying to get through. Narra quickly locked the door but she decided to add an extra layer of security as she tied the doors shut with some rope she had and collect her sword.

The deeper she got into this temple the more uncomfortable she felt. As she walked deeper into the temple the lower into the ground she seemed to go. The air grew colder as she went farther away from the light of the sun and she didn’t know if it was being underground or something more that was bothering her. She went down another set of stairs and knew she had never been this deep in the ground.

There had been chances over the years to enter the grand underground world of the dwarfs but she was a little scared of the Underdark because of the stories her Grandmother used to tell her about the creatures that lurked in the sunless world. Drow that would snatch you from your home to serve as a slave for the rest of your days, fearsome monsters that would control your minds and the terrible mind flayers with their twisted and appetites for brains. It was a world of endless suffering and dangers. She had fought some of the monsters her Grandmother spoke about especially the drow but some of the fear still lingered in her heart.

As if bringing her fear to life she saw a collapsed wall that had a hole showing a big tunnel into the Underdark that might lead to the surface. The hallway bent around to parts unknown and a nearby doorway revealed a gigantic library that would make a superior place to hide so she needed to decided what path to take.
15433333132.title: Look for a place to hide

154333331321.content:
The elf looked down the dark tunnel and decided the cultists were not going to check it out so she dove through the hole and rolled down the tunnel. Narra didn’t like the fact that the earth was soft because it meant she would leave a trail. As she moved she eyed the fading light of the temple wondering if she should remain close by because she was certain of how to get back to the surface world. Several of her enemies appeared at the hole and looked down the tunnel but thankfully their human eyes were far inferior to her elven ones but she needed to get out of here in case they decided to look further. She took several turns before she felt comfortable to sit and relax.

Her muscles cried out for rest and she was happy to give them what they asked for as she curled up into a small alcove pulling her cloak over her allowing her to fade into the rock. She had done the best she could to cover her trail with light careful steps but an expert tracker would be likely to find her and an inexperienced one might get lucky. Narra decided to not worry about what she couldn’t control and went into what the elves did instead of sleep.

She was still aware of the world around her but visions of her life passed before her eyes so she might review them and learn from them. For the next several hours she would be subjected to the random thoughts her mind thought she needed to see. It helped that the images and thoughts were distant, almost like viewing a painting or reading a story, because memories could often be disturbing things.

Memories of the tales told to her by her Grandma came back to her, likely to help her survive. Not all of it was frightening to her, hearing the voice of her beloved relative was wonderful to her ears. Finding food in this darkness wasn’t easy so she would have to keep her senses keen for the edible plants and animals down here. She had rations for three days left so she hoped she would be out of here long before they ran out but she couldn’t depend on it.

There was movement close to her and she almost broke from her rest to go check it out but she didn’t even know if what it was would notice her much less bother her. If she didn’t rest properly soon her strength would soon fail her in the combats she was likely to face but the noise made her nervous. Visions of the creeping dark elves and slithering things that she had been told about filled her head. Even as visions, they still caused her heart to race a little but she had faced many monsters her Grandma had told her about and come out on top. The fear faded from her but the sound grew closer to her, allowing the worry to remain.
154333331321.title: Enter the tunnel

1543333313211.content:
She was sure to hear strange noises in this unfamiliar place so she decided to ignore it even as it grew closer. Eventually, the sound of footsteps faded into the distance and she was able to finish her rest.
